The posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) is the strongest ligament of the human knee joint.	2.8958532735525497
Its origin is at the lateral wall of the medial femoral condyle and the insertion is located in the posterior part of the intercondylar area.	2.8665706628926424
From a functional point of view, one can differentiate fiber bundles with an anterior origin and fiber bundles with a posterior origin at the femur.	2.004986701980833
These fibers become tense when the knee is flexed.	2.0840479847056455
The posterior fibers insert in the posteromedial part of the tibial insertion and become tense when the knee is extended.	2.1716115527494053
The main part of the posterior cruciate ligament consists of type I collagen positive dense connective tissue.	2.596346426955158
The longitudinal fibrils of type I collagen are divided into small bundles by thin type III collagen positive fibrils.	1.9640684472734369
In this region, the structure of the tissue resembles fibrocartilage.	2.5797574595510713
Oval-shaped cells surrounded by a metachromatic extracellular matrix lie between the longitudinal collagen fibrils.	2.0605647379339396
The femoral origin and the tibial insertion have the structure of chondral apophyseal enthesis.	2.290217862405635
Near the anchoring region at the femur and tibia there should be various mechanoreceptors which might have an important function for the kinematics of the knee joint.	2.119764497062923
The blood supply of the PCL arises from the middle geniculate artery.	2.239733233911214
The ligament is covered by a synovial fold where the terminal branches of the middle and the inferior geniculate artery form a periligamentous network.	2.07519742041087
From the synovial sheath, the blood vessels penetrate the ligament in a transverse direction and anastomose with a longitudinally orientated intraligamentous network.	1.863427245087564
The distribution of blood vessels within the PCL is not homogeneous.	2.2012418284625506
We detected three avascular areas within the ligament: Both fibrocartilaginous entheses of the PCL are devoid of blood vessels.	1.9211716358889124
A third avascular zone is located in the central zone of fibrocartilage of the middle third region.	2.274623141732858
Atrial reentrant tachycardias (ART) are a potentially life-threatening complication in survivors of congenital heart disease surgery.	2.242175884879945
From July 1993 to December 1997, temporary transesophageal pacing was used to convert 29 tachycardia episodes in 19 patients.	2.1199904261433327
At the time of the first tachycardia episode, patients' ages were 1 month to 26 years (mean 9.8 yrs).	2.184273571553265
Time from operation to onset of first tachycardia episode ranged from 1 day to 19 years.	2.1299895012863836
Onset was within the first 2 weeks postoperatively in 6 patients and occurred later in 13 patients (1 to 19 years after operation).	2.357940327616124
Postoperative pacemaker implantation had been performed in 2 pts; 17 of 19 pts were receiving antiarrhythmic medication.	2.176563119550841
After placing a quadripolar transesophageal catheter, atrial and ventricular signals were recorded and atrial stimulation performed.	1.980172397874357
Atrial cycle length of tachycardia ranged from 160-380 ms with 1:1 to 4:1 AV conduction.	1.9654059293642991
Temporary transesophageal pacing was performed following an algorithm starting with 4 extrastimuli (20 ms below atrial cycle length of tachycardia).	1.8756294098855422
Tachycardia terminated in 27 of 29 cases (93%) without complications.	2.2556539424437605
In 3 cases, conversion was achieved by pacing after amiodarone 5 mg/kg i.v.	2.247899769665218
After tachycardia conversion, sinus- or pacemaker rhythm was present in 20 cases.	2.1837554476274756
In 9 cases atrial fibrillation was recorded; spontaneous conversion to sinus rhythm occurred after a maximum of 3 min (7 cases) or persisted and required direct current cardioversion (2 cases).	1.991005644476707

Epileptic seizures may alter autonomic functions.	2.4048898136959385
This is especially the case with complex focal seizures (of temporal lobe origin) and grand mal.	1.9957964263579597
Most frequently, such seizures cause ictal tachycardia, sometimes tachypnea, probably caused by the propagation of epileptic discharges to autonomic cerebral structures.	1.9290403775508058
Ictal bradycardia and asystole are rare phenomena.	2.357958169664404
However, they may be life threatening.	2.697068683390581
Their differentiation from primary cardiac arrest is possible by the use of ictal EEG and ECG registration.	2.4236494997502143
Postictal serum prolactin measurement does not differentiate syncope from seizure.	2.117445627496205

Even in a physician-staffed prehospital trauma care system, the chance of surviving a post-traumatic cardiac arrest is minimal.	2.0654825139359154

Intraarticular bleeding and muscle bleeding occur spontaneously or as a result of trauma in hemophilia A or B.	2.2761905504751243
The most common sites for hemarthrosis are the knees joints, elbows and ankles joints.	1.92970539771492
Resorption of intraarticular blood induces reactive hemophilic synovitis.	2.2225647881541106
Hyperplasia of the synovium can be followed by recurrent bleedings.	2.5201491028247682
These early reactions can change to a chronic synovitis and cause cartilage damage, finally resulting in a complete destruction of the joint.	2.264282331111736
Since 1981 158 adults and 61 children with a hemophilia A or B were treated at the Center for hemophilic disorders Frankfurt in an interdisciplinary approach.	1.9716889864048848
Consequent prophylactic treatment with factor substitution can prevent the incidence of severe hemarthrosis.	2.499008623707781
Minor joint bleedings are treated by adequate factor substitution, temporarily non-weight bearing of the extremity, application of ice-packs and physical therapy.	2.030009011105757
More severe joint hemorrhages should be aspirated in order to reduce the acute synovitis.	2.6814012963205713
This is followed by a consequent physical therapy (joint and soft tissue techniques) and anti-inflammatory drugs.	2.1866661223521326
The goal is a sufficient muscular balance of the joint, the improvement of the coordination, and the proprioception.	2.952388198672502
The chronic synovitis is less painful and poorly responses to conservative interventions.	2.0982877560697357
Local ice application, sytemic and local anti-inflammatory treatment support the physical therapy.	2.171260709965186
Soft heel shock absorber, elastic and semi-rigid bandages prevent recurrent bleeding episodes by shock absorption and decrease of synovial impingement.	1.7645931111787925
Synovectomy is indicated in cases of chronic persistent synovitis.	3.1889565730019234
Radiosynoviorthesis (RSO), which is an alternative in certain cases, has been performed with great success in 12 cases in our hospital.	2.707374914082488

A 72-year-old patient received 0.1 mg morphine by the intrathecal route and 2x1.5 mg midazolam as adjuvant therapy.	2.092929578484043
Severe respiratory depression and somnolence supervened 3.5 h later, which lasted over the next 24 h and necessitated intubation and mechanical ventilation.	1.9729748743182802
Continuous administration of >6 mg naloxone to antagonize the supposed effect of the morphine had no effect.	2.0933334827318255
The patient's condition was not normalized until a single dose of 0.3 mg flumazenil was administered.	2.0231887304836507
For the time being, especially in the case of elderly patients, we recommend that strict indications are adhered to when intrathecal administration of morphine is considered and that less than 0.1 mg morphine is given.	2.2857892211366813
Respiration should be monitored for quite some time.	2.5058355293945938
In contrast to the often debated NYHA classification, the determination of peak oxygen uptake (peak VO2) by cardiopulmonary exercise testing allows an objective assessment of the exercise capacity of patients with congestive heart failure (CHF).	2.1793221220988253
However, cardiopulmonary exercise testing is a time consuming and costly diagnostic tool, which requires sophisticated equipment and specially trained personell.	2.035664098934541
Exercise capacity can also be determined by the 6 minute walk test.	2.8094986991102586
This test simply measures the distance covered by strong walking on a hallway level within 6 minutes.	1.8960989487657738
The 6 minute walk test is a submaximal exercise test, which is associated with much smaller increments in heart rate, blood pressure and plasma catecholamines than cardiopulmonary exercise testing.	2.372101356042392
It is characterized by a very small intraindividual variance.	2.453387050398216
Furthermore, it can be easily performed and, due to low logistic and personal requirements, it is very cost effective.	2.6334323666342945
The results of the 6 minute walk test - as well as of cardiopulmonary exercise testing - are influenced by extracardial exercise-limiting disorders, such as pulmonary diseases.	2.3172127921537817
Independent from the etiology of CHF, the results of the 6 minute walk test are closely related to peak VO2.	2.443961546203308
Like peak VO2 the 6 minute walk test has been shown to be a predictor of morbidity and mortality in CHF, with its predictive value being independent from left ventricular ejection fraction and other potential prognostic parameters.	2.180571323523563
In CHF patients a walking distance < 300 m is associated with a one-year-mortality of up to 50%, whereas the one-year-mortality in patients reaching a walking distance > 450 m amounts to only a few percent.	2.7165506082742383
In addition, the hospitalization rate of patients reaching a walking distance of < 300 m is several fold higher than in those with a walking distance >= 450 m. Like cardiopulmonary exercise testing, the 6 minute walk test allows to control the efficiency of specific treatments and to monitor the natural course of the disease.	1.9422110719620311
The 6 minute walk test is, thus, a cost effective alternative to cardiopulmonary exercise testing in CHF patients.	2.2323828087103057
However, neither the 6 minute walk test alone nor the results of cardiopulmonary exercise testing alone are sufficient for selecting patients, e.g., for cardiac transplantation, as each individual case requires a synopsis of all relevant facts and parameters.	2.0598300140583663
We report the first case of prurigo pigmentosa in the German literature.	2.337889539803814

The effects of glycerol are discussed in detail.	2.325142678293803
Glycerol can lead to a transition of crystalline lipid structures within the horny layer lipids into liquid crystalline states.	2.1509337432386304
Especially if applied in oil/water-emulsions it improves, the hydration of the horny layers better than urea.	1.8873896284053686
In addition, if facilitates the dissolution of desmosomes within the superior layers of the horny layer enhancing desquamation.	1.899016761465328
Furthermore, by using glycerol, the mechanical properties of the skin can be influenced; long term used leads to increased elasticity.	2.3252779170235702
The roughness of the horny layer is reduced, which can be explained by the abrasive and/or the hydrating effect.	2.5216441490910997
Glycerol used in o/w-emulsions also protects against the influence of tensides or noxious lipophilic agents.	2.0134864898727405
Presumably a flux from the base of the epidermis towards its surface triggers the regeneration of the barrier.	2.1360092968172224

Patients presenting with facial trauma are initially evaluated with a systematic clinical examination because many fractures can be accurately diagnosed by inspection and palpation alone.	1.8486248837482178
In these cases plain film radiographs serve only for confirmation and documentation of the diagnosis.	2.165533440255652
In many other cases accompanying and extensive soft tissue swelling may clinically obscure fractures.	1.9432635521650103
A complete and accurate evaluation of these patients requires additional radiological imaging methods.	2.3964737827125417
A series of plain films may be generally sufficient but in most of the cases they can be regarded as initial screening methods for more thorough diagnosis with computed tomography (CT).	2.3531478283899188
In trauma patients CT is the imaging method of choice because it shows more fracture lines and displaced fragments than any other imaging modality.	2.0881471735848476
CT delineates soft tissue and bony structures and can localize and even characterize foreign bodies.	2.1483504385717933
A complete and accurate characterization of the fracture type and potentially associated complications is mandatory for the appropriate treatment and can only be achieved by careful radiological (CT) evaluation.	2.3606962346443474

Metastasis formation is a multistep process that requires tumor cells to progress through many different stages.	2.0907723599694097
One of the first steps is a disturbance of the epithelial integrity through a decrease in intercellular homotypic adhesion.	2.4257944626473407
Proteolysis of the extracellular matrix, as well as increased locomotion, leads to intravasation and dissemination of the tumor cells.	2.7488623559897425
Finally, neoangiogenesis is required for the initiation as well as the growth of the metastases, providing the tumor cells with both nutritive agents and growth factors.	2.4361024014032036

When the "quality profiles" of rehabilitation hospitals are compared ("benchmarking"), paying institutions of rehabilitation could gain information on the cost-quality-ratio of particular hospitals as well as important leads for improving the steering processes of patients and hospitals.	2.0900496377019855
In the present article, results of a first "field-run" of the procedures for measuring patient satisfaction and quality of rehabilitation processes are reported.	2.2791822925583136
A comparative analysis of patient satisfaction in four orthopaedic/rheumatologic rehabilitation hospitals showed high degrees of overall satisfaction in all hospitals.	1.9325982858601718
In several subdimensions of patient satisfaction, however, significant differences between hospitals were found.	2.75756600667109
Quality of rehabilitation processes - as assessed by a standardized peer-review - varied substantially between 36 hospitals.	2.00832783373657
Problems of quality were found especially in some dimensions that must be considered as crucial for rehabilitation, e.g., in the history and diagnosis of disabilities, in the consideration of psycho-social problems, or in the assessment of occupational capacities.	2.475958738827244
The analysis of THR-failures showed that the acetabular component still is the main problem of total hip replacement.	2.4122100180167116
The acetabular cup fails more often than the stem.	2.3362891895230833
In the midterm analysis the failure rate is a little bit higher in cementless than in cement fixed cups.	2.00096148241565
The known effect that the failure rate of cups fixed with cement increases exponentially 8 to 10 years after implantation, could of course not be seen in this study.	2.1170944239989526
The success of the cementless fixation was negatively influenced by the diagnosis rheumatoid arthritis, age over 70 and the fixation manner: the failure rate of threaded cups was higher than the one of pressfit cups although the Zweymüller-cup as well as the Link type V-cup showed good results.	2.0841170186266496
The midterm results of the stem were very good for the cementless as for the cemented technique.	2.395989760030335
Some implants showed compared to others significantly worse results.	2.275505753640432
The further implantation should be thought of, what partially has already happened.	2.031881352071754
Type I and type II diabetes are the most common types of diabetes.	2.712121435446573
The ratio of type I to type II diabetes is about 1:9.	2.4150564179554252
Type I diabetes is caused by an absolute insulin deficiency and is therefore referred to as insulin-dependent diabetes.The disease becomes manifest clinically in childhood or adolescence ("juvenile diabetes"), although manifestation in adulthood is being increasingly observed.	2.0013395570701533
Morphologically, a subtotal ( > 80 %) to total loss of beta cells in the pancreatic islets occurs.	2.1582567943692132
Lymphocytic insulitis, which disappears after the beta cells have been totally destroyed, is pathognomonic of type I diabetes.	2.028179259936429
This insulitis is an expression of an autoimmune event that is triggered by a multitude of factors.	2.241901561351842
An important factor appears to be a genetic predisposition (HLA DR3/DR4/DQ8) in connection with as yet unknown environmental factors (e. g., viruses).	2.127574313121362
Autoantibodies, such as islet cell cytoplasmic antibodies (ICA), insulin autoantibodies (IAA), and/or autoantibodies to the GABA-synthesizing enzyme glutamic acid carboxylase (GAD), are already detectable in a prediabetic phase, although it is not possible to predict the time of clinical manifestion.	2.2976087073220244
The course of the disease is dependent on age.	2.9989708917892717
Young children require insulin therapy sooner than juveniles or adults.	2.0620389217838193
This article summarizes data from recent studies on the prevalence, diagnosis and therapy of the obstructive sleep apnea syndrome (OSAS) in children.	2.39774367737782
The prevalence of this disorder in 4-6 year old children is 0.7%.	2.5022781613990417
Leading clinical sign in 90% of patients is habitual snoring, but this is rather nonspecific, as 60% of patients investigated for habitual snoring do not have OSAS.	2.1622213874281497
Other signs such as daytime sleepiness, failure to thrive, profuse nocturnal sweating or mouth breathing are equally nonspecific.	1.8614093365288868
The diagnosis, therefore, has to be confirmed by polysomnography, where OSAS is suggested by the occurrence of >5 obstructive apneas/hypopneas per hour of sleep in conjunction with a CO2 of >50 mmHg for >8% of sleep time and/or >1 desaturation to <=90%/h.	2.239338549349621

The majority of patients with symptomatic spondylolysis can be treated conservatively.	2.888752961664783
Only when symptoms persist in spite of conservative treatment surgery may be indicated.	2.460780928245523
In young patients, however, fusion of a mobile segment should be avoided, but a direct repair of the pars defect can be attempted.	2.6144290193428152
This procedure allows complete healing and possibly avoids degeneration of the intervertebral disk.	2.100993334153074
For this purpose Morscher developed the hook screw, which connects the arch with the anterior articular process.	1.8415622246128363
It allows compression of the defect without crossing the defect with the screw.	2.3780191767788033
A follow-up study of the first 33 patients with a follow-up time of 3.5 years on average showed a good subjective result in 79 % of the patients.	2.8949164012126296
The reason for the better results in young patients is that in older patients the origin of the pain is often not the pars defect, but the degeneration of the intervertebral disk.	2.5339126989783876
Direct repair of spondylolysis is therefore indicated when pain persists after 6 months of conservative treatment or there is a progressive olisthesis of not more than 10 mm.	2.24309102692173
After the end of growth an MRI study of the intervertebral discs should show whether there is degeneration or not.	2.3277974469896296
Direct repair is indicated only in the absence of disc degeneration.	2.817114055618436
After the age of 25 years this procedure should not be carried out.	2.8513716594466816

Evaluation of the weaknesses of completed antiarrhythmic trials.	2.1586218054684467
Problems in the specification of indications and in the estimation of the effective sample size cannot be solved by the inclusion of mixed populations but require the establishment of development programs.	2.1686879091074505
Further crucial points are the appropriate choice of control and the identical concomittant treatment and observation of the groups to be compared.	2.108756932422389
Technical mistakes as imprecise definitions, arbitrary decisions during the course or at termination of a trial, unclear responsibilities or an unscheduled flow of information can be avoided if these potential problems are anticipated in the trial protocol.	1.9413716380370851
A prospective approach that anticipates problems at the time the study protocol is drafted is preferable to a reluctant reactive approach during the course of the trial.	2.2773617232182835

The operative realignment of mechanical axis deviations (MAD) is necessary to prevent early joint degeneration and to reach normal load-bearing.	2.0922143273165004
Modern types of external fixation systems allow an alignment of the mechanical axis to exact degrees.	2.1506298177210224
Predominantly this are corrections of angular deformities.	2.3460986131540817
In some cases the analysis of the MAD does not show any angular deformity, but a parallel staggering of the mechanical axis lines of a bone.	2.2671053612579555
Such parallel staggering of the mechanical axis lines is defined as a translation deformity of the bone.	2.2908581102078975
In combined deformities with angulation and translation the centre of deformity can be established proximal or distal out of the limit of the bone.	2.2166134484970934
In translation deformities the realignment of the mechanical axis requires a parallel re-staggering made by a translation-osteotomy or by a counterangulated double osteotomy.	1.8808421238214557
In complex deformities with angulation and translation, the translation requires a separate corrective planning.	1.9504431786898797
By using external fixator systems to perform acute or progressive corrective osteotomies the position of the Axis of Correction of Angulation (ACA) in relation to the n-CORA of the deformity has to be considered.	1.980298468521073
These geometric effects to corrective osteotomies can be calculated by using simple trigonometric formulas or graphical methods.	1.9126683395599353
Possibilities to compensate translation and length effects are shown by using unilateral external fixator systems.	2.1035729610195926

Fifty-eight percent of the patients expected the therapeutic goal "healing", whereas from the physician's standpoint this was realistic in only 7 % of cases.	2.164699969216887
The specific radiotherapy-related expectations "tumor control" and "pain relief" reached almost the same levels in patients and physician (71 % vs 71 % and 40 % vs 44 %).	1.9948352970603715
Patients with healing expectancy reported higher quality of life at the beginning of the therapy (53.4 % vs 39.9 %); patients expecting pain relief reported lower quality of life (37.1 % vs 54.5 %).	2.117158467482576
Surgical patients who had been operated on within the past year (n = 18) showed a particularly high healing expectancy (83 %), whereas patients whose operation dated back more than 1 year focused on pain relief as therapeutic goal (83 %).	2.151402962789303
The surgeon, as the primary contact person for patients, can influence patients' therapy-related expectations.	2.3044132361117735
In explaining the overall therapeutic strategy, surgeons should also mention the scope and limits of adjuvant therapies.	1.9590803792305755
The meanings of the terms "quality", "quality of care", and "quality management" were clarified with common international definitions.	2.19653847370683
Based on that, the basic ideas, concepts, and objectives of quality management in medicine were explained.	2.127060957802037
Finally some future trends related to quality were viewed, which represent challenges for the medical profession and entire medicine.	1.9552764571126255
The papular-purpuric "gloves and socks" syndrome (PPGSS) was first described in 1990 by Harms et al.	1.8306487013589232
The syndrome is characterised by fever, an itchy erythema with edema, confluent papules and purpura of the hands and feet in a "gloves and socks" distribution.	1.9706028821135961
The skin lesions may be associated with purpura and superficial erosions of the oral mucosa.	2.4879243153561186
Viral infections, in particular parvovirus B19, are the most likely trigger.	2.867409075417361
In the present case PPGSS developed after taking trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole.	1.9660360388685916
Since the patient developed identical symptoms after accidental re-challenge with the same drug, this case strongly suggests medications as another factor in the pathogenesis of PPGSS.	2.1730668077034387
Most fractures of the clavicle heal well with nonoperative treatment.	2.7923660514821504
On rare occasions, malunited clavicular fractures are associated with a pattern of disability that includes not only pain but also functional or neurovascular impairment.	2.023152166093126
In these cases, clavicular osteotomy and correction of the deformity should be considered.	2.293697665062689
In four patients with a malunited fracture of the clavicle following nonoperative treatment, we performed a clavicular osteotomy for deformity.	2.591348648891431
In all four patients the clavicular fracture healed with shortening associated with pain and ipsilateral glenohumeral dysfunction.	1.961395463926911
The deformity was not associated with neurovascular dysfunction.	2.364260443564141
In preoperative X-ray studies, the shortening of the malunited clavicle was between 0.9 and 2.2 cm in comparison to the contralateral clavicle.	2.3773879574016257
All patients underwent an extension osteotomy of the clavicle with interposition of an autogenous iliac crest bone graft.	2.160524812631013
The follow-up was 1 - 4 years postoperatively.	2.7745293000551046
The functional outcome was evaluated using the Constant-Murley and the UCLA score.	2.1664097582900252
All patients had immediate pain relief following osteotomy and correction of the deformity.	2.230594789661397

Necrotizing pancreatitis is still associated with considerable morbidity and mortality.	2.3798893806380046
Formerly, surgical treatment with early and extensive pancreatic resection has been the standard.	2.5584599014987255
Improvements in our understanding of the pathogenesis of the disease and progress in the field of intensive care therapy have made conservative therapy the initial standard in the treatment of necrotizing pancreatitis.	2.9537875527278663
A considerable percentage of patients with sterile necrosis can be managed with low morbidity and mortality by conservative treatment without operation.	2.787774622062828
Nevertheless, surgical treatment is indicated in patients with infected necrosis and in sterile necrosis if multiorgan failure persists over a limited period of time despite maximum intensive care therapy.	2.361462659977683
Pancreatic resection should be abandoned for surgical treatment of pancreatic necrosis, as results with regard to morbidity, mortality and long-term outcome are unsatisfactory.	2.634154022126174
Today the surgical standard is careful digital necrosectomy, which must be followed by either postoperatve drainage, repeated open lavage or continuous closed lavage.	1.8646752274213432
In experienced hands, all three procedures provide similar results with regard to morbidity and mortality.	2.3638936964460044
The aim of quality management in rheumatology is to improve care and outcome in patients with rheumatic diseases.	2.620242503987613
This can be achieved by means of prospective long-term observation of the patient with regular documentation of clinical, radiological, biochemical and functional data using certain validated scoring methods (DAS, radiological score, ADL score Hanover or Health assessment questionnaire, SF36, etc.).	2.151203399368593
Long-term observation and documentation including radiographs have been performed in the rheumatology hospital in Ratingen for 20 years without even knowing the term quality management.	1.9496329254970297
Quality management in a hospital for rheumatic diseases begins with certain structural prerequisites: possibility of direct admission of a patient to the hospital by the family physician, outpatient clinic to investigate and to follow patients over a long period of time, multidisciplinary team with specialists in rheumatology, orthopedic surgery, physiotherapy, ergotherapy, special care, psychological, and social services, close cooperation with specialists in neurology, dermatology, ophthalmology, etc., department of radiology, special laboratory, facilities for internal diagnostics and treatment.	1.8846533337274116
The hospital needs a training program for the qualification of rheumatologists and orthopaedic surgeons.	1.9864231517132145
The hospital staff should closely cooperate with the doctors in private practice who admit patients and should continously support patient organizations.	1.9187268754471944
The quality of outcome is influenced by the process quality which depends on the following factors: selection, training and motivation of the hospital staff; supervision of clinical assessment and documentation by senior physicians, daily x-ray demonstrations and case reports, interdisciplinary case demonstrations at least every week in addition to daily consultation, team reports, regular education including review of actual literature for physicians, education programs exchanging knowledge with physiotherapists and nurses, and regular education programs for patients.	1.8733481831488035
Process quality can only be achieved by an interdisciplinary approach and regular communication between all participants including the patient, whose opinion must be noted and regarded.	2.266727966544666
As far as possible, the same doctor who treats the patient in the hospital should follow her/him in the outpatient clinic.	2.2058612625895173
The quality of outcome can be improved by regular reinvestigation of the patient with control of medication, side effects, efficacy, documentation of clinical, biochemical, radiological, and functional data.	2.2900453370847096
Decisions for further treatment have to be based on these follow-up data.	3.3494659653550802
A standardized follow up and documentation system for all rheumatology units with prompt feedback could definitely improve the quality of rheumatologic care in Germany.	2.0471716745865125

There is controversy about the amount and relevance of postoperative CO2 resorption.	2.184530610057858

The goal of this prospective study was to investigate the amount of CO2 resorbed from the abdominal cavity in the postoperative period by means of CO2 metabolism.	2.648272936753225
After giving informed consent to the study, which was approved by the local ethics committee, 20 patients underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy.	2.505325247545534
All patients received general endotracheal anaesthesia.	2.315143192995581
After induction, total IV anaesthesia was maintained using fentanyl, propofol, and atracurium.	2.0342309627716038
Patients were ventilated with oxygen in air (FiO2 0.4).	2.1174615149255764
The intraabdominal pressure during the surgical procedure ranged from 12 to 14 mm Hg.	2.317010229527828
Thirty minutes after releasing the capnoperitoneum (KP), CO2 elimination (V.CO2), oxygen uptake (V.O2), and respiratory quotient (RQ) were measured every minute for 1 h by indirect calorimetry using the metabolic monitor Deltatrac according to the principle of Canopy.	2.067422985672178
Assuming an unchanged metabolism, the CO2 resorption (V.CO2) at any given time (t) can be calculated from V.CO2 (t)=V.CO2 (t)-RQ (preop) V.O2 (t).	2.1026872552993088
It was thus necessary to define the patient's metabolism on the day of operation.	2.3856452695322896
The first data were collected before surgery and after introduction of the arterial and venous cannulae for a 15-min period.	2.386603319858131
Measuring point 0 was determined after exsufflation of the KP and emptying of the remaining CO2 via manual compression by the surgeon at the end of surgery.	2.1295067669196763
Patient's tracheas were extubated and metabolic monitoring started 30 min after release of the KP for 60 min.	2.0841860226111395
Simultaneously, a nasal side-stream capnometry probe was placed and the PeCO2 and respiratory frequency (RF) were obtained by the Capnomac Ultima (Datex) and registered every minute as well.	1.8252041008684252
Values were averaged over four periods of 15 min each.	2.214124478897403
An arterial blood gas sample was drawn at the end of every 15-min period.	2.407538705245415
Postoperative pain was scored by a visual analog scale and completed by a subjective index questionnaire on general well-being.	2.033691879615567
All data were analysed by the Friedman or Wilcoxon test; P<0.05 was considered significant.	2.011580929823455
The findings do not indicate CO2 resorption in the postoperative period after laparoscopic cholecystectomy (Tables 2 and 3, Fig.	2.1974677727411467
Arterial CO2 as well as PeCO2 were elevated postoperatively (45 mm Hg vs. 36 mm Hg intraoperatively), while V.CO2 and V.O2 were unchanged when compared to the preoperative measuring period.	2.244493544580955
The postoperative RF was comparable to preoperative values.	2.3960388029302973
Calculated CO2 was lower than 10 ml/min and within accuracy of measurements.	2.6971684452558318
The postoperative pain index ranged between 3 and 4, and 3.75 - 15 mg piritramid was administered.	2.0351554031604464
All patients feld tired immediately after the operation, but scores improved slightly at the end of the 60-min period of metabolic monitoring.	2.255555622738521
There is no significant resorption of CO2 from the abdominal cavity later than 30 min after releasing the KP.	2.098611070146117
Up to this time, any CO2 remaining in the abdominal cavity after careful emptying by the surgeon has been resorbed and exhaled.	2.0132811622030755

The clinically (C1) and sonographically (C2) evaluated pretherapeutic stages were compared to the postoperative histopathologic tumor classifications.	2.116286229469165
The clinical staging was correct in 75.0 %, high in 7.7 %, low in 17.3 %, the N-stages were correct in 59.2 %, high in 17.7 %, low in 23.1 %.	1.8463300759974344
The sonographic staging was apparently superior with the T-classifications correct in 92.3 %, high in 7.7 %, low 0.0 %.	1.938901910898262
The N-stages were correct in 89.6 %, high in 9.2 %, low in 1.2 %.	2.0845602779956227
The accuracy of combined TN classification rose from clinical 46.5 % to 84.6 % by sonography.	1.9110361117195134
Accompanying inflammations, foregoing biopsies and tooth extractions were the main reasons for incorrect staging.	2.1338846361615236
Therefore, the thorough sonographic investigation performed after the clinical examination and before invasive procedures, due to little patient discomfort, good availability and high accuracy, is an excellent sectional imaging method for staging, therapy-planning and follow up of tumors of the head and neck especially of the orofacial regions.	2.198367101242008
Standardized guidelines for exercise training for patients with chronic congestive heart failure (CHF) have not been established.	2.7647573953830795
In the past CHF patients involved in exercise training studies demonstrated a wide range of cardiac and functional impairment, with an ejection fraction between 18 and 35% and a peak VO2 between 12.2 and 25.4 ml/kg/min on average.	2.0041130265986293
For determination of training intensity, a VO2 between 40 and 70% of peak VO2 and/or training heart rate between 60 and 80% of peak heart rate was used.	2.1158154376814355
There was also a wide range for frequency (between 3 and 7 times per week) and duration of training (between 20 and 60 min per session).	2.102101022784008
For aerobic exercise training only continuous training methods were applied.	2.216055306072299
We have developed a new interval training method which allows intense exercise stimuli on peripheral muscles with minimal cardiac strain.	1.886725055739034
After only three weeks of training, the improvement in aerobic capacity was similar to that reported after longer training periods using continuous methods.	2.0064291371694924
To determine work rate for work phases of interval training, a special steep ramp test was developed.	1.9507040495072854
By analysis of acute physical responses to this testing procedure and to the interval training, both were proven to be tolerable in CHF patients, even if their ejection fraction is as low as 13%, or peak cardiac index not greater than 1.6 l/m2/min, and peak VO2 less than 8.5 ml/kg/min.	2.015646573035072
Small (T1) and exophytic (T1, T2) tumors are suitable for radiotherapy.	2.0891642308523894
Limited lesions (T1, T2) can be cured by functional endoscopic resection techniques or external partial laryngectomies.	2.0995406044640044
Extensive tumors (large T2; T3) are treated by total laryngectomy or by primary irradiation, especially in the case of a good response to induction chemotherapy.	2.3383713365779846
When radiation treatment fails, surgery succeeds in more than half of the cases.	2.372437925965164
Tumors infiltrating or transgressing the laryngeal framework (T4) can only be cured by total laryngectomy followed by radiotherapy.	2.0478493947827032
Subtotal or circular ablation of the adjacent pharynx or esophagectomy needs repair with visceral or myocutaneous grafts.	1.9900754818077093
Inconspicuous lymphatics should be treated electively in most cases, with the exception of early glottic cancer.	2.7817110316489355
Induced hypotension is defined as a reduction in mean arterial blood pressure to 50-60 mm Hg in normotensive subjects.	2.523380062163872
The aim of induced hypotension is to decrease intraoperative blood loss, decrease the need for blood transfusions and improve operating conditions.	2.2758137012862
Most studies indicate that induced hypotension can decrease intraoperative blood loss by 50% in many surgical procedures; however, some studies report that blood loss is not significantly reduced.	1.9904641173778903
Current methods of induced hypotension are based on the use of rapid and short-acting vasodilators as primary agents (nitroprusside, nitroglycerine, urapidil), supplemented by volatile anesthetics (isoflurane) and/or -blockers (esmolol) to improve effect, reduce dosage and prevent side effects (reflex tachycardia, tachyphylaxis, rebound hypertension).	2.0239735138984947
Proper positioning of the patient and controlled ventilation aid in reducing blood loss.	2.691897260287414
Major risks of induced hypotension are a reduction in blood flow (i.e.	2.6604948870984564
ischaemia) of vital organs (brain, myocardium) and elevation of intracranial pressure in neurosurgical patients.	2.145427974905972
Thus, major contraindications of induced hypotension are severe coronary artery disease, hypertension combined with arteriosclerosis of cerebral vessels and increased intracranial pressure in patients with cerebral disease.	2.3201147464542013
Complications are rare in otherwise healthy patients, but may be higher in elderly patients and those with underlying organ dysfunction.	2.6355524646352655
Therefore, careful assessment and selection of patients, together with consideration of the potential complications, appropriate choice of drugs and invasive beatby-beat monitoring, are essential for the safe practice of induced hypotension.	2.270533703892848
Abstract  Empirical results stemming from infant research have contributed extensively to the understanding of coping with psychosocial stress and vulnerability for psychosomatic symptoms in later life.	1.8849840612397595
The interaction and the emotional exchange between caregiver and child in the first months of life lead to representations of interactions that will be the base for the quality of attachment.	2.167549878862871
The mutual regulation of the caregiver-infant-pair enables the child to acquire a psychic capacity to regulate physiological requirements.	1.9303683238430487
This selfregulatory function determines the potential of the later adult to react to distress - in a symbolic way using words or more in a somatic way by developing psychosomatic symptoms.	1.8665601809602141
First experiences with the treatment of psychosomatic patients with respect to the new findings about self-regulation are reported.	2.7204067291850107
A 31-year-old pregnant woman had to undergo emergency abdominal surgery due to acute intestinal obstruction.	2.357413118686472
The patient's preoperative history demonstrated multiple allergies as well as abdominal trauma several years before.	2.4665787433526063
The physical examination - including sonography of the two fetuses - showed no pathological signs.	2.268399216894867
Anaesthesia was induced intravenously with the operating table tilted to the left side, using routine precautions pre-oxygenation, and rapid sequence intubation, and was maintained unproblematically.	2.0245978935297453
About 20 min after the onset of surgery, hypotension, tachycardia, and a drop in oxygen saturation appeared.	2.6610951629282353
Volume substitution and the application of vasoactive drugs failed to stabilise the haemodynamic situation.	2.3054655713128223

The development of eyelid edema led to the diagnosis of an anaphylactic reaction.	2.5881263179434795
The patient was treated successfully with epinephrine, antihistamines, and corticosteroids (prednisolone).	1.9767686698432958
The suspicion of latex-related allergy was verified postoperatively by radio-allergen-sorbent test (RAST) and prick and scratch tests.	1.7673064108667758
The mean arterial blood pressure is decreased during the first two trimesters of pregnancy and increases to preconceptional values during the last weeks of gestation.	2.3632347273900414
The heart rate increases during the whole course of pregnancy.	2.266796804114424
During late gestation fewer patients show an increase in diastolic blood pressure and heart rate in the standing position.	2.428686446134215
A fall in heart rate was only seen in this period.	2.5407108502005222
A fall in mean arterial blood pressure during standing is not related to the blood pressure in the supine position during the whole course of pregnancy.	2.309462384247395
The hypotensive symptoms are twice as frequent during early pregnancy compared to late pregnancy.	2.01321072161216
Headaches, fatigue and cold extremities are the most usual complaints.	2.4503960235304354
The frequency and intensity of these three symptoms decrease during gestation.	2.2537912075349995
Blood pressure in the supine position is reduced in symptomatic pregnant women.	2.2608874927008724
However, the occurrence of these symptoms is not correlated to the fall in blood pressure in the standing position.	2.394152772513411
The Birth-weight is not influenced by blood pressure in the supine position, but depends on the fall in blood pressure during standing.	2.2568506825180257
Pregnant women with a more pronounced fall in blood pressure give birth to newborns with a lower birthweight.	2.159965911734992
These results imply a hitherto unknown cause of intrauterine growth restriction.	2.08702180591036
The combination of saltwater baths and subsequent ultraviolet irradiation is an effective treatment for psoriasis and atopic dermatitis.	2.108890948763842
The aim of the present study was to determine the photosensitizing properties of two commercially available bath salts, original salt from the Dead Sea and sodium chloride.	1.8429641581421812
To address this issue, test areas on the volar aspects of the forearms were soaked with salt solutions for 15 minutes prior to ultraviolet-B (UVB) irradiation.	1.8498722139928885
The salt concentrations tested were 1%, 3% 5% and 15%.	2.2780861239463066
Tap water followed by UVB and UVB alone served as controls.	2.0665877027562365
Erythema was determined by visual and photometric measurement, and delayed tanning was assessed by colorimetry.	2.2353241328355278
Erythema obtained by wetting the skin prior to UVB irradiation was more pronounced than erythema induced by UVB alone.	1.9829546879952056
The most prominent erythema was yielded by tap water+UVB.	2.058779260311713
The salts had a differing photosensitizing capacity and the strongest erythema was produced by the 5% solutions.	2.033339028814497
There was only a moderate influence on delayed tanning by bathing the skin prior to irradiation.	1.9941408302404713
The results from the present study indicate that soaking the skin with salt solutions or tap water increases skin sensitivity to subsequent UVB irradiation.	2.140545120427437
This may contribute to the effectiveness of salt water baths followed by UV irradiation and may account for an increased sunburn risk after bathing.	2.2351728284457644

Cor triatriatum dexter is a rare congenital malformation in which a membrane divides the right atrium into two chambers.	2.4638680332128096
The membrane represents a persistence of the right sinus venosus valve (RSV).	2.3653421744196383
Normally the RSV regresses between the 9th and 15th week of gestation, as the cephalic portion forms the crista terminalis and the caudal portion develops into the Eustachian and Thebesian valve.	1.7878512909411022
Any failure in the regression process may result in remnants of RSV as a simple muscle bar, a Chiari-network or a fenestrated or unfenestrated membrane (cor triatriatum dexter).	1.7998024495142493
We describe a patient with cor triatriatum dexter in whom diagnosis was made several years after successful valvulotomy procedure for severe congenital valvular pulmonary stenosis.	1.9219903581839677
Therefore, dynamics of hematopoiesis is mainly defined by these two parameters.	2.1160684640741327
However, since only few data are available from previous studies, we performed a retrospective analysis to elucidate some aspects of this complex pathomechanism.	2.4492588324813043
Apoptosis was detected in bone marrow tissue by the ISEL-technique and topoisomerase II  expression was demonstrated by the monoclonal antibody Ki-S1.	2.002139880797326
Furthermore, by determination of the proliferating-cell nuclear antigen labeling (PCNA) index, we were able to calculate the proportion of cells in the G2/M phase, because both nuclear antigens are expressed in different phases of the cell cycle.	2.0345266860690785
Patients with IMF, PV, and ET revealed a normal range of apoptosis, whereas in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) a significant increase could be observed.	2.1265638390973116
On the other hand, IMF and PV were characterized by a raised proliferative activity.	2.0851993188639906
Dynamics of hematopoiesis was assessed by calculation of the so called hematopoietic turnover index.	2.3584460652391863
In CML and reactive lesions no alterations of this parameter were detectable, but IMF and PV showed a significant increase.	2.22055944837493
Survival analysis disclosed a relevant worsening of life expectancy for patients with reduced apoptosis and proliferation.	2.398785335712361
In conclusion, our in-situ results confirm and extend previous experimental data on hematopoietic cell kinetics.	1.9789482657217596
In this context, a greater regenerative capacity of hematopoiesis may be reflected by an increased rate of apoptosis and/or proliferation and therefore is associated with a more favorable outcome.	2.319880567833523

The capacity for the release of O2 to the tissues is especially excellent.	2.2634928857224725

Numerous studies have demonstrated that epidural anaesthesia and pain relief by epidural analgesia reduces perioperative stress responses and thus may reduce postoperative morbidity and mortality.	2.0645401840409927
In patients undergoing vascular surgery, epidural anaesthesia diminished postoperative hypercoagulability.	2.1774985122815353
These patients may benefit from less thromboembolic complications as well as a reduced risk of a re-operation.	2.5856757593249675
However, regional anaesthesia does not affect cardiopulmonary morbidity or overall mortality significantly in most clinical studies.	1.9746347961677897
One reason for this disappointing finding may be the missing integration of improved postoperative pain relief into general surgical care.	2.0831250739523415

The rigidity of varicose veins was higher than that of normal veins; there was no difference between the varicose vein above a competent valve and the "normal" vein below this competent valve.	2.0922560312293332
The matrix proteins demonstrated an increase in total fibres, whereas the elastic fibres were reduced and fragmented, explained the rigidity of varices.	2.248320950692468

Guanine nucleotide-binding proteins (G proteins) function as transducers of information across the cell membrane by coupling receptors to effectors.	1.8578366441983443
A large number of G protein-linked receptors funnel extra-cellular signals as diverse as hormones, growth factors, neurotransmitters, and primary sensory stimuli through a set of G proteins to a small number of second-messenger systems.	1.8847330498422816
The G proteins act as molecular switches with an "on" and "off" state governed by a GTPase cycle.	1.9168178103517906
By virtue of its high affinity and specificity for guanine nucleotide binding and its intrinsic GTPase activity, the -subunit of the G protein (G) plays the critical role in regulation of the effectors by their corresponding G protein.	1.7976971437970326
Mutations of G may result in either constitutive activation or loss of expression mutations.	2.199800620076804
Given the variety of functions subserved by G protein-coupled signal transduction, it is not surprising that abnormalities in G protein-coupled pathways can lead to diseases with manifestations as dissimilar as blindness, hormone resistance, precocious puberty and neoplasia.	1.9195437961570494
For a given defect in a G protein-coupled pathway, the extent of the manifestations will also be determined by the cellular distribution of the affected component.	2.3587292870383894
Defects in components expressed exclusively in a single cell type will cause more a focal disorder than defects in a widely expressed component, particularly in germline mutations (e.g., Albright's hereditary osteodystrophy), whereas somatic mutations of genes encoding even an ubiquitously expressed component can cause focal disease when the somatic mutation itself is focal (e.g., McCune-Albright syndrome).	1.7698542249734686

Reperfusion injury has become a scientific problem of increasing importance, in part because of recent developments of thrombolytic therapy.	2.2838671762265506
The mechanisms of reperfusion injury following focal cerebral ischemia, however, are not known in detail.	2.4365554957050017
Recent studies strongly suggest that reactive oxygen species (ROS) and calcium overload play an important role in reperfusion injury and that pharmacological interventions against calcium- or free radical-mediated damage could extend the therapeutic window in cerebral ischemia/reperfusion.	1.8080347130172798
The mediators involved are known to induce a mitochondrial permeability transition (PT) during the reperfusion period, which is associated with uncoupling of mitochondrial respiration, loss of mitochondrial membrane potential, and a burst production of ROS, leading to cellular death.	2.2545638011772073
The mitochondrial PT is considered to be a key process in reperfusion injury following cerebral ischemia, as also observed in other organs such as heart and liver.	2.237810489374616
Pharmacological modulation of mitochondrial permeability changes have the potential to reduce tissue damage due to reperfusion.	2.181997292010792

The purpose of this study was to compare the initial stiffness of two techniques for posterior interbody lumbar fusion (PLIF) by a finite element approach.	1.8503668421838397
Thus a finite element model of a human L3/4 spinal segment was generated.	2.1753287453280654
Stiffness of the intact model was tested under compression (600 N), torsion (25 Nm) and shearing forces (250 N) without preload.	1.8682579857301054
The results were compared to the stiffness following simulation of PLIF with two BAK-Cages and PLIF with two Harms-Cages and additional posterior screw-rod-osteosynthesis.	1.8384595566532944
PLIF with two BAK-Cages resulted in a loss of stiffness in compression, torsion and shearing.	2.0438497253110004
PLIF with two Harms-Cages and posterior osteosynthesis resulted in an increase of stiffness in compression, torsion and shearing.	2.035977679134587

25 of 27 patients with SCCH showed a characteristic high bullhorn-like uptake of the sternocostoclavicular region with the manubrium sterni representing the skull and the inflamed sternocostoclavicular joints corresponding to the horns (=bullhorn-sign).	1.7544874637054062

In combination with PPP or psoriasis pustulosa, the typical scintigraphic bullhorn pattern enables the diagnosis of PAO (19 patients) with high confidence.	2.1634327895996877
Patients with SCCH but without skin disease at the time of presentation (8 of 27 patients) may develop PPP later and, therefore, it is justified to classify them as incomplete PAO with high risk to develop other skeletal manifestations later in the course of the disease.	2.117942734269931

She was in good health and her family history was unremarkable.	2.16499664792773
Histologic examination of the hyperpigmented patches revealed pigmented filiform downgrowths of the interfollicular epidermis and follicular infundibula, as well as small epithelial cysts.	2.17857903657634
Upon immunohistochemical and ultrastructural studies, the number of melanocytes appeared normal.	2.6914693399602694
The elongated dendritic processes of the melanocytes contained many mature melanosomes.	2.0923140998785894
In the adjacent keratinocytes large melanosomes did not aggregate into complexes.	2.0052756326501497
The diagnosis of localized reticulate pigmentary disorder was established.	2.1677033976089004

Methods: The present study comments the efficacy of laparoscopic antireflux surgery after required Nissen fundoplication of 70 patients.	2.37432697981143

Results: Preoperatively, we found a low general GIQLI score (mean 92.7 points), which increased 6 weeks postoperatively (116.8 points), 3 months (124.8) and 1 year (mean 123.9 points) significantly and is now comparable to the healthy population (122.6 points).	2.070993246252655
Conclusion: It is our opinion that the efficacy of the treatment of gastroesophageal reflux disease with required Nissen fundoplication can also be documented and discussed by using QOL.	2.681920964094907

No patient died after surgery and none had to be reoperated on.	2.570348405788662

We examined the prevalence of HIV-associated cutaneous disorders as well as the frequency and efficiency of UV-radiation in HIV-infected patients by evaluating the clinical records of 1310 patients seen between and 1994 and 1996.	2.2964375862582047
41 patients were treated with UVB-radiation and 4 patients with UVA1-radiation, while three patients received PUVA-therapy.	2.328277359881034
UV-radiation proved to be efficient and safe in the treatment of pruritic papular eruption, atopic dermatitis and psoriasis.	2.45979806308176
Although some in vitro studies and studies with transgenic mice have suggested a negative impact of UV radiation on the immunosystem of HIV-positive patients, no progression of the HIV infection due to phototherapy has been proven.	1.975483390320216
The staff at interventional radiological procedures is exposed to high levels of ionizing radiation.	2.218175748089642
This applies especially to measures at cardiac catheterization laboratories.	2.1630598146167443
In this study the annual radiation exposure to the staff was estimated by measuring the dose rate under characteristic conditions.	1.9598056335758403
It could be shown that the resulting radiation exposure was strongly dependent on the radiation protection measures and is also dependent on the operation conditions of the x-ray tube.	2.3694882512686535
The effective dose for the physician wearing a lead apron and thyroid shield was detremined to about 1.7 mSva.	1.8757902511736602
Without a thyroid shield an effective dose of about 3.5 mSva resulted.	2.1659870244089325
This corresponds to approximately the natural background radiation of about 2.4 mSva in the Federal Republic of Germany.	1.9656710331473768
From the number of procedures performed we could derive an effective dose of approximately 1-2 µSv per application for the physician, averaged over all types of procedures.	2.233292282297835
Further, it could be shown that the readings of the film badges, usually worn by the staff, underestimate the effective dose by approximately a factor of two.	1.9845278062678535
This is because the film badges do not include the contribution of the unshielded parts of the body to effective dose.	2.147177451216247
From the estimated annual effective dose, a lifetime dose of 68 mSv was estimated for a 40-year working career.	1.9078917165881615
The corresponding lifetime risk for induced fatal cancer due to radiation exposure was determined to 0.3% applying the ICRP risk factor of 4  -  10-2 Sv-1.	1.9359600861950101
Considering the NCRP recommendations for a safe occupation, working in a cardiac catheterization laboratory can be considered as safe when applying all radiation protection measures.	2.1014989354988702
However, changing the protection measures and modifying the parameters of the x-ray-tube can lead to strong changes of the radiation exposure and the resulting risk estimation.	2.398639434741402
Treatment of pulmonary hypertension is an important issue in intensive care.	2.8035568758995173
One therapeutic regimen involves the intravenous administration of prostacyclin (PGI2).	2.056816361276856
Thus, its clinical usefulness is limited.	2.447320398298273
However, the inhalation of vasodilators such as nitric oxide (NO) or nebulized PGI2 causes a selective pulmonary vasodilation in ventilated alveoli and improved gas exchange, without any systemic vasodilation.	1.7718612012037147
It has therefore gained importance for the treatment of pulmonary failure associated with high shunt fractions.	2.6865141454874624
However, the inhalation of vasodilators may have adverse effects: in the case of NO, toxic side effects are predominant (MetHb, NOx), whereas in the case of PGI2, technical problems in terms of dosing and administration safety are of major interest.	2.2382493468926463
Furthermore, some patients do not respond to the treatment.	2.5906652251131597
The exact pathophysiological mechanisms remain to be investigated.	2.439806929074025
The treatment of infrarenal aortic aneurysms by means of transluminally placed endovascular prostheses reflects significant progress in the field of vascular surgery.	2.278595365449931
In the case of infrarenal aortic aneurysm it is possible to achieve technically successful implantation of such a prosthesis in well over 90 % of cases.	2.251764941203841
The rate of clinical success, meaning lasting effective exclusion of the aortic aneurysm, cannot (yet) be definitively determined, since no long-term results are so far available.	2.1010989449940674
Secondary leaks are observed in at least 10 % of all patients, making a further therapy necessary (endorepair, conversion, embolization).	2.3423134093433586
Further development of endovascular prostheses will include optimization of the aortal/iliac attachment of the prostheses, a better configuration and the development of long-lasting materials that can be used for endovascular prostheses.	2.4882773962635008
The frequency of postspinal headaches after accidental puncture of the subarachnoid space with 16 - 18 G Tuohy needles is reported at 59 - 85%.	1.7744541878319806
A case of postspinal headache syndrome persisting over a period of 6 weeks following epidural anaesthesia during labour is described.	2.043038904706215
A 30-year-old women had severe postspinal headache for 6 weeks after epidural anaesthesia during labour.	2.4008119729071833
Conservative therapy for 3 days and 4 days of bedrest followed by cristalloid infusions during a 3-week hospital stay and a subsequent 3-week period of bedrest at home did not lead to lasting pain relief.	2.0375104550757914
Intracranial haematoma and other abnormal processes were excluded by CCT.	2.212066891925643
A pathologic EEG was not confirmed by cranial MRT.	2.218352747434945
A lumbar epidural blood patch of 15 ml of autologous blood was performed at L3/4.	2.412566852803102
The patient stayed in bed for 12 h. After 3 h free of pain the patient complained of recurring headache.	2.0301846859551738
After a further 48 h of bedrest she had recovered.	2.1825008954752434
Because of lumbar pain 4 days after the epidural blood patch a MRT was performed, which showed the blood at L4 to S3 in the epidural space.	2.2171150542547555
The diagnosis of a cerebrospinal fluid leakage was based on the history and the main symptom of postspinal headache: the pain onset in the supine position.	2.399339342893243
Such possible treatments as diminishing subarachnoidal pressure by bedrest, increasing cerebrospinal fluid production by infusions, increasing epidural pressure by epidural infusions and closing the cerebrospinal fluid leakage by epidural blood patch are discussed.	1.7644038219526392
The average success rate with the epidural blood patch is 93%.	2.283581523164147
Volumes ranging from 5 to 20 ml are discussed for the autologous blood.	2.2160376515059963
We chose 15 ml of blood, to take account of the possibility that blood might settle in the wide sacral space.	2.1566086905840502
We were able to document the position of the blood patch as L4 to S3 on MR tomography (the injection site was L3/4).	2.1790907053697555
Most patients are free of headache 1 h after epidural blood patch.	2.313425254131986
Our patient had to be confined to bed for another 48 h because of recurring headache.	2.3280898031665
The blood patch alone was not immediately sufficient to prevent all further cerebrospinal fluid leakage.	2.080441975275484
Probably more than one subarachnoidal puncture had been made during the difficult epidural anesthetic procedure.	2.2248479075429044
On the other hand, the leak was probably only diminished because of the blood patch descending down to the wide sacral space.	2.108950900493166
The combination of the large-volume blood patch, which diminished the leakage, and conservative treatment, which narrowed the transdural pressure difference, was successful: the 6-week postspinal headache was cured.	1.9226287303051257
Prolonged postspinal headache should be treated by epidural blood patch.	2.6181782623289696
The use of over 10 ml cannot be generally recommended, although in this case most of the blood patch of 15 ml was localized caudally.	2.2882487145480837
Careful monitoring for side effects is necessary with blood volumes larger than 10 ml.	2.142612178488254
If the headache persists a second blood patch should be performed, with the volume and the probable caudal spreading of the first taken into account.	2.45526207373969

Nasopharyngeal carcinomas (NPC) belong to the most frequent malignant tumours in certain parts of the world, e. g., south-east Asia, while they occur infrequently in western  Europe.	2.1445095961676066
The association of NPCs with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), a transforming human herpes virus, is well established.	2.036906824150201
The current WHO classification recognises two major NPC histotypes, non-keratinising NPC and squamous cell NPC.	2.069211763709882
EBV is invariably present in non-keratinising NPCs and the viral oncoprotein LMP-1 (latent membrane protein-1) is expressed in some cases.	2.376469619873742
The tumour cells of non-keratinising NPCs show phenotypic features which are inducible by LMP-1 in  vitro.	2.1008370719778533
Furthermore, the virus is detectable in nasopharyngeal carcinoma in situ.	2.047447126041339
Thus, the virus is likely to be involved in the pathogenesis of  non-keratinising NPCs.	2.876778197688667
By contrast, the association of squamous cell NPCs with EBV  displays a geographical variability.	2.3116392650196325
It appears, therefore, that squamous cell NPCs are a heterogenous group of tumours distinct from non-keratinising NPCs.	2.1286516541403784

Between 1977 and 1996, 45 patients with astrocytoma, 14 with oligodendroglioma and 18 with mixed glioma received postoperative radiotherapy with a median total dose of 52 Gy (range, 45 to 61 Gy).	1.9916912729509242
The influence of various factors including histology, gender, age, seizures, duration of symptoms (<= 6 weeks vs > 6 weeks), CT pattern (enhancement vs no enhancement), type of surgery, total radiotherapy dose and timing of radiotherapy on relapse-free survival and overall survival was investigated.	1.9883435322617937
The median overall survival time was 81 month, the 5- and 10-year survival rates were 54% and 31%, respectively.	2.274600319244776
The median time to progression was 56 months, while the 5- and 10-year progression-free survival rates were 45% and 24%.	2.20425334248047
Univariate analyses identified the total radiotherapy dose (p = 0.01), duration of symptoms (p = 0.05), the presence of seizures (p = 0.04), and the CT pattern following intravenous contrast (p = 0.005) as significant prognostic factors for overall survival.	2.6089817562486344
Progression-free survival rates were influenced by the total dose (p = 0.04), the duration of symptoms (p = 0.01) and CT pattern (p = 0.006).	2.7503575228298347
On multivariate analysis, only the CT pattern (enhancement vs no enhancement) remained as independent prognostic factors for both progression-free survival and overall survival.	2.0243882676801204
A minimum total dose of 52 Gy is recommended for the postoperative radiotherapy in low-grade glioma.	2.5097527092885845
Tumors with CT enhancement seem to need further intensification of treatment.	2.0903181734912173

Sensory NCV and cortical median nerve evoked potentials remained normal.	2.1118346924781815

Since systemic treatment of neuropathic plantar ulcers in diabetics (DNPU) has so far been rather ineffective, recent reports of successful management of DNPU by short-term retrograde transvenous leg perfusions (RVP) by South American angiologists encouraged us to apply this treatment method in diabetics suffering from chronic DNPU.	1.746715253009449
Hence, in a prospective comparative clinical trial started in 1989 we have treated 45 male diabetics suffering from DNPU with the same daily doses of netilmycin, administered either in systemic venous infusions (SVI: n=21, three times/day) or in RVP (n=24, once/day).	1.9620095072268549
After 10 consecutive days of treatment, ulcers had closed in 8 of the 24 patients treated with RVP, as against 3 of the 21 treated with SVI.	2.1583967784393874
Diminution of the ulcer area by >30% including full debridement was achieved in 10/24 of the RVP cases (SVI: 4/21).	2.0229137936509254
During 6 months of follow-up, amputation of toes or forefoot was necessary in only 1 patient in the RVP group, but in 4 in the SVI group.	2.3826378299952173
Partial restitution of osteolytic damage was observed in some cases after RVP.	2.63981161483975
Our results show that regional netilmycin therapy given by the RVP procedure is clearly superior to equal netilmycin doses administered by SVI for the treatment of DNPU.	2.0747103618267615
RVP can be recommended in DNPU, particularly when the ulcers are complicated by infections.	2.358710865690395
There is hardly any other discipline that illustrates the conflict between the freedom of science and research, that is to say, ultimately, what is medically possible, and human dignity and the protection of life or, in other words, what can be justified in ethical or legal terms, so clearly as reproduction medicine.	1.7819010385956164
The topics involved in this conflict cover a broad spectrum, ranging from in vitro fertilization with subsequent implantation of the embryo through the problems of multiple pregnancy and selective feticide, the many questions raised by assisted fertilization, and especially by anonymous sperm donation, and the controversial techniques of preimplantation diagnosis and cryopreservation, to the legal aspects of prenatal diagnosis, some of which have already been the subjects of cases decided in the supreme courts.	1.9622703171667701
In a good many of these sectors it is difficult to reconcile what doctors can do and what it is admissible for them to do, so that it is hardly surprising that there is often no general consensus.	1.9620684987438008

Selection criteria are: 1.	2.749181345732882
CEAD- >5 cm 2. expansion rate >=5 mm/6 months 3. involvement of the critical aortic segment III/IV.	2.075527891195414
TAP consists of: 1. left posterolateral aortotomy from Th 8 - L 2, 2. excision of the intraaortic dissection membrane(s) 3. aortic closure to a diameter of 3 cm to reduce wall tension.	1.9125924003067543
All 5 patients survived without any major complications, particularly no paraplegia.	2.2999950848201958

All optically active molecules have at least one asymmetric atom in common which is attached to four ligands, that can have different three dimensional positions.	1.9448388044404392
Therefore it can be concluded that the resulting isomers are chemically identical in all respects except for the direction with which they rotate plane-polarized light.	2.008054751850455
When the isomer and its corresponding enantiomer are present in equal proportions, they are called racemic mixture, a mixture that does not rotate polarized light, since the optical activities of the two isomers cancel each other.	1.9279207243402854
Although the isomers are chemically identical other optically active molecules can interact with these isomers in a geometrically specific way termed stereoselectivity.	1.806066017824253
The human body comprises a chiral environment due to optically active proteins; thus it is not surprising that enantiomeric drugs exhibit different pharmacological properties, when used as pure optical isomers.	1.8921284813684849
Till today most modern anaesthetics have been optical isomers, which are mainly used as racemic mixture (1:1 mixture).	2.065819724472246
For financial reasons pure isomers were only used for research purposes, but nowadays the wide clinical use of pure isomers is financially feasible due to new production techniques.	1.9088990406823048
The terms eutomer and distomer were chosen to indicate the more or less potent form of the drug.	2.257897892626341
Among the modern anaesthetics ketamine, isoflurane, bupivacaine and atracurium exhibit an asymmetric carbon.	1.9281741444300395
For most drugs the separation in pure isomers will reduce side effects.	2.0354248877883934
For volatile anaesthetics this question is still unanswered, since experimental and clinical results are inconsistent so far.	2.1313775789253846

In this contest, MRI pulse sequences and scanning methods serve one of four primary roles: (1) speed improvement, (2) device localization, (3) anatomy/lesion differentiation and (4) temperature sensitivity.	2.127754395875276
A 74-years old patient is admitted to the hospital with a over a period of 4 years growing, scrotal, ulcerated tumor.	2.21254331797966
There is no connection to the testicle or the epididymis palpable.	2.0519628590050814
All laboratory findings including the tumorparameters are normal.	2.2841457525432562
The scrotal sonography shows a solid tumor, that is filled with vessels in the Doppler sonography.	2.1346551963155114
The complete tumor resection with histological examination leads to the diagnosis of a scrotal leiomyoma.	2.647483092442852
This rare, benign tumor is a differential diagnosis to paratesticular or non-germinal tumors.	2.291498707664711
Although most of them are very rare, knowledge about their reproducible clinicopathological features is important to avoid diagnostic pitfalls.	2.4471840576087662
These lesions include: bacillary angiomatosis, a vasoproliferative, pseudoneoplastic infection of immunocompromised patients caused by Rochalimaea henselae; tufted angioma, a variant of lobular capillary haemangioma characterised by a "cannon-ball" distribution of multiple lobules composed of packed capillaries and pericytes; microvenular haemangioma, a cutaneous haemangioma composed of thin-walled and irregularly branching blood vessels which dissect dermal collagen; sinusoidal haemangioma, a distinctive variant of cavernous haemangioma which may be located in the subcutaneous breast tissue and then may be confused with well-differentiated angiosarcoma; "hobnail haemangioma" (targetoid haemosiderotic haemangioma), a benign vascular tumour with a distinctive clinical targetoid appearance and a hobnail cytomorphology of the prominent endothelial tumour cells; retiform haemangioendothelioma, a very recently characterised low-grade angiosarcoma occurring most commonly in the extremities of adolescents which is characterised by arborising blood vessels arranged in a retiform pattern and lined by hobnail-like prominent endothelial cells; Kaposi-like infantile haemangioendothelioma, a borderline malignant tumour of infants mimicking Kaposi's sarcoma histologically; epithelioid angiosarcoma, a highly aggressive tumour in the spectrum of epithelioid vascular lesions which stains positively for endothelial and epithelial immunohistological markers; benign lymph-angioendothelioma (progressive lymphangioma), a benign, slowly growing macule or plaque which has to be distinguished from well-differentiated angiosarcoma and Kaposi's sarcoma; and lymphangiomatosis of the limbs, a poorly recognised angiomatosis occurring in young patients and limited mainly to the limbs with a favourable prognosis.	1.6449770004468538

Experimental animal models of ventricular arrhythmias have been developed to investigate the mechanisms of arrhythmogenesis in man.	2.7721246809851605
Ventricular arrhythmias associated with ischaemia and infarction often cannot be elucidated by clinical studies on patients because those arrhythmias are potentially lifethreatening and their occurrence is unpredictable.	1.8790893507602675
Because of additional experimental procedures and techniques that can be used in the animal laboratory, such as microelectrode recording of transmembrane action potentials and high-density optical and electrical activation mapping, animal models have provided information that cannot be obtained from clinical studies.	2.2677647814865245
Studies on animal models have provided new ideas and hypotheses that have been tested in clinical studies and that have been found to be true for clinical arrhythmias.	2.3925914446372727

The authors report a rare, recently diagnosed and atypical mishap during one-lung ventilation (OLV) via a double lumen tube (DLT) and left-sided thoracotomy: an ipsilateral pneumothorax during ventilation of the right lung.	1.9950319856360135
This occurred in a 63-year-old patient with chronic obstructive airway disease who was scheduled for urgent repair of a descending thoracic aortic aneurysm.	2.16822763496843
Anaesthesia and surgery were uneventful until aortic cross-clamping release.	2.2059656712926565
The common presentation of increased intrathoracic extrapleural pressure owing to a pneumothorax in patients with mechanically ventilated lungs is a rapid decrease in oxygen saturation, followed or paralleled by haemodynamic deterioration.	2.008494935639259
Although the above presentation could be seen in this case, the diagnosis of a tension pneumothorax was delayed twice.	2.8390904187234973
First, symptoms were initially obscured by haemodynamic changes resulting from a head-down tilt and aortic declamping.	1.9805089763553068
Second, since the lack of consolidation after aortic declamping focused attention on the airway problems, complications resulting from the use of a DLT were primarily considered.	2.292689780720396
In particular, since breathing sounds were detectable initially, malposition or torsion of the DLT had to be excluded by fibre-optic bronchoscopy, which involved a further delay.	1.9195884093173445
Finally, two observations led to the diagnosis of a right-sided tension pneumothorax: (1) bullae of the contralateral lung, detected during thoracotomy; (2) the finding that ventilation of both lungs and the left lung subsequently increased arterial (SaO2) and mixed venous oxygen saturation (SvO2) and the circulatory status, but ventilation of the right lung caused a deterioration.	2.249586238261061
Chest radiography and insertion of a chest tube with drainage of air, thereafter, validated our hypothesis.	1.9785861847075628
The time course of oxygen desaturation during OLV and tension pneumothorax was as severe as expected; the time course of haemodynamic deterioration, however, appeared quicker and had more impact than expected.	2.1143076977306925
Assuming that mediastinal deviation was not hindered by contralateral intrathoracic pressure during thoracotomy, we believed that circulation should be depressed later or to a lesser extent in patients with an intraoperative pneumothorax.	2.115024500251876
Yet, during thoracotomy, decrease in cardiac filling and output during tension pneumothorax in OLV obviously results primarily from the immovability of the mediastinum owing to mediastinal fixation and is at least as decisive as the contralateral intrathoracic pressure in closed-chest patients.	1.8013917695038608
In summary, a tension pneumothorax during one-lung ventilation and thoracotomy is a rare, but disastrous complication during the use of a DLT, which has not, to our knowledge, been reported previously.	2.326194918758063

Introduction: The goal of this study was to compare contrast-enhanced T1-weighted Flash and Turbo-Flash sequences with conventional spin-echo sequences as a basis for planning high-precision radiotherapy.	2.0470897069142695
Methods: A total of 25 consecutive patients with different intracranial tumors and a disrupted blood-brain barrier were studied.	2.3564859092729793

The evaluation of the three sequences included the measurement of the signal- and contrast-to-noise ratios, the visual inspection of the tumors and artifacts, and the measurement of tumor size.	2.633948435358674
Results: The signal- and contrast-to-noise ratios were significantly (P < 0.05-0.01) lower for Flash and Turbo-Flash than for conventional spin-echo sequences.	2.0265370816342485
However, visual inspection of the contrast-enhancing tumors revealed in 23 and 24 of 25 lesions on Flash and Tu-rbo-Flash images, respectively, good or very good tumor visibility when compared with conventional spin-echo images with a reduction of imaging time by a factor of 7-8.	1.9648560205604475
Tumor sizes were comparable in all three techniques.	2.6975548845641453
Conclusion: At present, conventional spin-echo images are superior to fast Flash and ultrafast Turbo-Flash sequences as a basis for accurate target volume definition in high-precision radiotherapy.	1.9483728365987316
However, fast Flash and Turbo-Flash images may be a practicable alternative to conventional spin-echo images for tumors in the posterior fossa or in patients unable to tolerate a stereotactic fixation device.	1.9952501163766538
Despite some limitations, Turbo-Flash sequences enable fast dynamic MR imaging combined with an acceptable morphology, which may be sufficient for target volume planning in high-precision radiotherapy.	1.9929475686560285
