However, the role of mitoxantrone in escalating treatment of patients with frequent and severe relapses and with rapid progression of disability is less clear.	2.2481884052591354
In this retrospective analysis we report on 15 patients with severe relapsing-remitting (9 patients) and secondary progressive MS with superimposed exacerbations (6 patients) treated openlabeled with mitoxantrone in our Clinical Research Group from July 1994 to October 1998.	1.9658009508528766
Eleven of these patients (73%) were treated with azathioprine, interferon-beta-1b or cyclophosphamide before.	2.6296066960364137
The patients received mitoxantrone over a period of at least 12 months (19 +/- 6 months) with a single dose of 10 mg/m2 monthly for the first three months.	2.739750392427365
Thereafter, infusions were repeated every 3 months (total dose 141 mg +/- 45 mg).	2.100318711415494
The annual relapse rate could be significantly reduced from 3,0 +/- 1,5 in the year before therapy to 0,5 +/- 0,5 during therapy.	2.369615644167204
Nine patients (60%) were stabilised, while four patients (27%) showed an improvement of disability.	2.3079866638061466
The treatment was well tolerated with only minor side effects.	2.292510580009434
These results although retrospectively obtained confirm previous trials showing that mitoxantrone may be useful in MS patients with frequent and severe exacerbations and/or a rapidly progressive course of the disease who have had other immunomodulatory medication.	2.1324912184533305
Interstitial cystitis (IC) represents a rare and complex inflammatory bladder condition in which diagnostics can be challenging.	2.0104063981447244
Strict NIH criteria for its diagnosis were designed for research purposes.	2.2763417907052563
Their routine application would miss large proportions of IC patients.	2.1271700768190036
When IC is suspected, history and physical exam are followed by an evaluation of long-term voiding diaries.	2.5251027318614137
Large voided volumes (functional capacity >250 cc) or longer micturition intervals (>2 h.), absence of nocturia or symptom-free periods reduce the likelihood of IC.	1.904058869159288
Further exclusion diagnostics include urine tests (infection), cytology (in-situ carcinoma), ultrasound (calculi, bulks, anomalies) and urodynamics in selected cases.	1.7663294623818904
Bladder capacity measurements under sedoanalgesia are of limited value, since functional low-volume bladders can be mechanically extendable.	1.9116403649348759
Cystoscopy under general anesthesia represents the diagnostic standard procedure for IC during which 90% of IC-patients present with characteristic mucosal glomerulations after bladder distension.	1.8991271222782387
Biopsies are recommended for exclusion of malignancy.	2.635576675757058
Similarly, complex determinations of novel IC markers (histamine, tryptase, cytokines, growth factors, substance P, nitric oxide) are of no relevance in clinical settings and should be restricted to research projects.	1.9466723093105889
According to semiotics, which may be defined as the doctrine of the essential nature and fundamental varieties of signs, objects, and interpretants, pain is considered to be a sign (significant) with very different meanings (significance) either as a naturalistic symptom (of disease) or as a symbol used in a metaphorical context.	1.9629871984630471
When following this methodological perspective it is possible to interpret medical as well as poetic writings on equal terms.	2.4194654811440413
In Graeco-Roman medical texts pain was mostly understood as a result and an indicator of disease, but nonetheless as a symptom which seemed to be actively produced by the affected body.	2.0211802331843542
Aristotle (4th century B. C.), Celsus (1st century A. D.), and the famous experimental physiologist Galen (2nd century A. D.) agreed that pain was a sign of evil which should be fought without exception.	1.996807977041725
It was Galen who added the disturbance of function (functio laesa) as the fifth cardinal sign of inflammation to the four well-known cardinal signs of Celsus (rubor, calor, tumor, dolor).	1.850867611789848
He also coined the term µK to characterize an attack of migraine.	2.014282296493809
In algotherapy, Galen used a complex pharmacological system which was based upon the four cardinal qualities of humoral pathology.	2.013212164981518
In Homer's Odyssey (8th century B. C.), pain appears transformed into the shape of a scar which is visible and palpable on the hero's leg like an identification tag, whereas in Virgil's Aeneids (1st century B. C.) pain symbolizes weakness and defencelessness which can only be alleviated by the goddess Venus.	1.7102976231336944
Attention is mainly focused on detection of residual curarisation.	2.2922160286865276
New insights in the pathophysiological consequences of residual neuromuscular blockade and the actual criteria of complete recovery are discussed.	2.0830133498858596

A lack of standardisation of neuromuscular monitoring is probably the major problem on the way to a widespread utilisation of the monitoring.	2.176090292011466

Twenty four patients with clinically suspected lesions of the anterior cruciate ligament underwent MRI of the knee on both 0.2-T and 1.0-T MRI units.	2.5942377285103393

Frequency of these signs was determined for both modalities, and observer agreement was assessed using the kappa statistic.	2.016575508918553
In 8 patients the 1.0 T unit showed neither primary nor secondary signs for tears of the anterior cruciate ligament; in these patients the 0.2-T unit detected primary signs in 1/8 cases (12 %), and secondary signs in 3/8 cases (37 %).	2.245689967989973
Observer agreement was very good for the 1.0-T unit and fair for the 0.2-T unit.	2.1778251340355563
There is no substantial difference between 1.0-T units and 0.2-T MRI units in the visualisation of primary signs of tears of the anterior cruciate ligament.	2.0377043740519407

As to the reproducibility of the results, the 1.0-T unit is far superior to the 0.2-T unit.	2.44871695830596

Scintigraphic imaging identifies pathophysiological processes; in other words it assesses regional perfusion, permeability, leukocytic accumulation and bone turnover.	1.886332983260183
These processes precede morphological changes and this accounts for the high sensitivity of nuclear medicine procedures as well as the low specificity for the differential diagnosis of different diseases with similar pathophysiological characteristics.	2.347703212950427
This review (1) describes and evaluates the currently used scintigraphic procedures, (2) suggests their differential use in certain clinical settings in comparison with alternative radiological methods and (3) addresses new developments in diagnosis using nuclear medicine procedures.	2.13349085788699
In summary, we advise dynamic bone scanning as a primary scintigraphic investigation.	2.09663498262491

Mammographic screening leads to a significant reduction of breast cancer of 30 % in women ages 50-59 years.	2.469633760336214
In younger women (40-49 years) the benefit accounts to only 20 % and has not proven to be statistically significant.	2.170108608886774
Nevertheless, the major advantage of mammographic screening is detection of the non-palpable tumor <= 10 mm in size.	2.3819217822662337
The treatment of these small breast carcinomas leads to long-term survival rates of >= 90 %.	2.6044328335787665
Mammographic screening programs have been introduced in the USA, Canada, Iceland and Sweden for women in their 5th decade of life.	1.9942345128615995
Starting yearly lifelong mammography-screening at the age of 40, the theoretical cancer induction by radiation exposure does not exceed 0.1 %.	1.9951125400467686

In Germany, screening-mammography is only introduced in patients at high risk for breast cancer.	2.2528085416328096

The hydrostatic pressure of spinal fluid is responsible for buoyancy of the brain within these compartments.	2.2845745538721594
In patients with craniectomy this equilibrium is exposed to atmospheric pressure.	2.0735514837550086

Intensity changes of the pixels within previously defined radial image sectors were quantified in relationship to time and depicted as sector curves.	1.9508405369621038
The healthy adults demonstrated a characteristic pattern of two motion maxima that appeared within almost all sector curves.	1.9098781289645552
These maxima represented bolus transport movements and the reset movement of the tongue.	2.195470754175667

Previous investigations showed the anaesthetic potency of S-(+)-ketamine to be three times higher than that of R-(-)-ketamine.	2.131934622669008
It was the aim of this study to compare the effects of S-(+)-ketamine and racemic ketamine on endocrine and cardiovascular parameters, recovery, and side effects in geriatric patients during total intravenous anaesthesia (TIVA) for orthopaedic surgery.	2.128034518799219
Forty patients over 60 years of age scheduled for elective hip or knee replacement were investigated in a double-blind, randomised design.	2.3008624331421657
For induction of TIVA, patients received 0.1 mg midazolam, 0.5 mg atropine, 1 mg/kg S(+)-ketamine or 2 mg/kg racemic ketamine, respectively, 2 mg vecuronium, and 1.5 mg/kg suxamethonium.	2.2842420021289467
After intubation and relaxation with a total dose of 0.1 mg/kg vecuronium, a continuous infusion of 2 mg/kg per hour S-(+)- or 4 mg/kg per hour racemic ketamine was administered throughout surgery.	2.282277523203914
Blood samples were taken through a central venous catheter at seven time-points, before induction as well during and after surgery, until the 1st postoperative morning for analysis of adrenaline, noradrenaline (by high-pressure liquid chromatography with electrochemical detection), anti-diuretic hormone (ADH), adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), cortisol (by radioimmunoassay), glucose, and lactate.	1.8122487830397684
In addition, systolic arterial pressure (SAP), heart rate (HR), and arterial oxygen saturation were measured, and the time intervals between the end of ketamine infusion and the return of consciousness and orientation were protocolled.	2.3469253171145588
The incidence and assessment of dreams and other side effects were reported by the patients.	2.5107095638725294
Biometric data of the groups were comparable, the mean age of both groups being 68 years.	2.6288825354337946
Plasma adrenaline, noradrenaline, ADH, ACTH, cortisol, and glucose as well as SAP and HR increased significantly (P<0.05) during the course of anaesthesia.	2.438350991651316
The influence on lactate levels was not significant.	2.3880321039428862
There were no differences between S-(+)- and racemic ketamine with respect to these parameters.	2.429531813339458
Three patients in the ketamine-racemate group showed severe arterial hypertension and were withdrawn from the study.	2.2478129788185464
Recovery clearly improved after administration of S-(+)-ketamine compared to the racemate.	2.63402309052235
Simple orders were followed after 2.0 +/- 3.4 versus 4.9 +/- 6.8 min (P=0.07), orientation with respect to person returned after 5.7 +/- 4.0 versus 14.6 +/- 10.0 min (P<0.001) and spatial orientation after 8.2 +/- 5.4 versus 17.4 +/- 9.7 min (P<0.001).	1.8690870188843498
After racemic ketamine, 1 patient remembered a negative dream and 1 patient a positive dream.	2.177324067924623
In the S-(+)-group, 1 positive dream was reported.	2.3242479868165633
No intraoperative awareness was reported, and all patients would accept the same anaesthesia again.	2.1708252033832998
Increases in cardiovascular parameters and insufficient reduction of the stress response with respect to ADH, ACTH, and cortisol seem to require a more potent hypnotic element during TIVA with ketamine.	2.0776178870141777
With regard to endocrine and cardiovascular parameters, the pharmacodynamic effects of racemic and S-(+)-ketamine were comparable.	2.0361479939545046
Because of the significant improvement in recovery and the reduced quantitative drug load, S-(+)-ketamine offers a clinical advantage compared with currently used racemic ketamine.	2.000780752490296
The closure of large circular defects on the scalp is technically difficult and cosmetically often not satisfying, if a free transplant is necessary.	1.9643520778922392
Following the technique of Tillmann described first in 1908, several flaps shaped like a windmill can be combined.	1.9961780684255785
We report on 14 patients (ages 41-88 years) where large defects resulting from the excision of various tumors (5 melanomas, 5 basal cell carcinomas, 1 keratoacanthoma, 1 trichilemmal cyst, 1 squamous cell carcinoma, 1 skin metastasis) were successfully closed by this method.	1.8827785968896238
The diameter of the defect ranged between 4 and 8 cm (mean 5,7 cm).	2.360602570748657
Size and number of the rotating flaps (3 or 4) was varied according to the size of the defect and the mobility of the surrounding tissue.	2.467607497296127
The procedure was performed with local anesthesia in all cases.	2.7159915234646737
Wound healing occurred without complications except in 3 cases.	2.4248068966501406

The cosmetic result was rated "very good" in 71,4% and "good" in 14,3%.	2.204564809615123
The preservation of the terminal hair turned out to be of special advantage.	2.4713368446156143

Hearing aids have fundamental disadvantages: (1) stigmatization of the patient; (2) the sound is often found to be unsatisfactory due to the limited frequency range and undesired distortion; (3) in many patients, the ear canal fitting device generally necessary leads to an occlusion effect; (4) acoustic feedback when amplification is high.	2.4438703548391443
Conventional hearing aids transmit sound into the ear canal via a small microphone.	2.207283786357812
Sound has the disadvantage of requiring high output sound pressure levels for its transmission.	2.1288613860581207
This along with the necessary miniaturization of the loudspeaker as well as the resonances and reflections in the closed ear canal contribute to the disadvantages mentioned.	2.270525532287493
In contrast, implantable hearing aids do not make sound signals but micromechanical vibrations.	2.000874471432851
An implantable hearing aid has an electromechanical transducer instead of the loudspeaker of a conventional hearing aid.	2.207171225489776
The hearing signal does not leave the transducer as sound but as a mechanical vibration which is directly coupled to the auditory system bypassing the air.	1.8539750733777811
This implantable hearing aid is either coupled to the tympanic membrane, the ossicular chain, the perilymph of the inner ear, or the skull.	2.321541408165193
Corneal cells are known to participate in the regulation of local inflammatory processes by secretion of cytokines.	2.408271273164202
As the corneal endothelium may be exposed to endotoxin in organ culture and endotoxin is known to trigger inflammatory reactions, we investigated the effect of endotoxin from E. coli on organ cultured donor corneae with respect to autocrine and paracrine functions and the endothelial viability and density.	1.939853327765575
For the majority of patients with sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) many available hearing aids often do not achieve satisfactory results.	2.2005002374551057
For these patients partially implantable hearing devices have been developed, allowing distortion-free hearing and speech intelligibility that may be superior to conventional hearing aids.	2.1367613542394572
The external parts of partial implants, however, may result in a patient's stigmatization.	2.6576687298647315
Furthermore, they do not use the acoustic properties of the external auditory canal.	2.5084042423943593
Recently, we published the successful development of the first totally implantable hearing device for the treatment of SNHL (HNO 46 [1998] 853-863).	2.324384374593492
Here we report the first implantations of this unique, totally implantable electronic hearing system in patients with SNHL: Implex TICA LZ 3001.	2.1588039429472445
The implant microphone is implanted subcutaneously in the outer ear canal near the ear drum.	1.9960980154950918
The signal is processed by a digitally programmable multichannel audioprocessor located subcutaneously on the bony skull behind the ear.	1.8245289007993548
A piezoelectric transducer is coupled to the body of the incus and drives the ossicular chain by vibratory actions.	2.11303075257741
Energy is provided by an implantable battery.	2.595633471890169
Implanted patients describe hearing as being distortion-free and transparent.	2.281776770714217
Speech intelligibility and the hearing of music are improved.	2.238916371821653
Patients may achieve better speech discrimination, especially in the presence of background noise.	2.7268860951495175
The aid can be used during sports, including swimming.	2.746424837488221
To our knowledge, this is the first report of the implantation of a totally implantable electronic hearing system in patients.	2.0415555679944384
These results encourage further implantations of the totally implantable hearing system in the course of an ongoing clinical study.	2.3670273828568473

To prevent those growth disturbances all primary and secondary (4-day X-ray control) displaced fractures of the radial condyle, i. e. those with a central gap of more than 2 mm, were prospectively treated by open reduction and osteosynthesis with a metaphyseal lag screw beginning 1974.	2.236665680835434
Sixty-six patients (41 boys, 25 girls) with an average follow-up of 10 years (2-22 years) sustained 28 primary and 6 secondary displaced fractures.	2.314605040366152
In 5 cases a K wire fixation was performed in view of the smallness of the fragment.	2.462194309524137
Two children with conservative treatment following overlooked displaced fractures showed condylar overgrowth and varisation of the elbow.	1.9830804557860806
Screw osteosynthesis led to symmetric elbow angles and function in all cases, whereas fishtail deformities could be observed in 8 of 27 children, probably as a consequence of the remaining central fracture instability.	2.285648343929229
Conclusion: Open reduction and osteosynthesis with a metaphyseal lag screw prevents condylar overgrowth in displaced fractures of the radial condyle by guaranteeing fracture healing in anatomic position within 3-4 weeks.	2.0248600977563096
However, fishtail deformity can not be prevented by metaphyseal compression only.	2.2952864515780305

No side effects were seen following the concentrate infusions.	2.368903554098303
With this substitution treatment no specific symptoms of hereditary angioneurotic oedema were recognized in either case.	1.9543904010901523
The measurement of C1-INH plasma concentration 2 h or 4 h after C1-INH substitution showed a marked rise in both patients, though normal values were not reached in either.	1.9604017463031673

This can result in herniation into the lumen with obstruction of the tube.	2.387399373439309

Nociception is a protective system of the body which prevents it from injury and tissue damage.	2.3365636722382424
Human beings respond to noxious stimuli by moving away.	2.226749443645454
They learn by pain to avoid these situations in future.	2.250335511139685
Shortly after major injury, there is a limited analgesic period allowing the body to flee the area of danger, later on, emerging pain compels the body to rest and supports recuperation.	2.086005000291046
While acute pain has a certain meaning, chronic pain does not.	2.245652709577435
It induces a comprehensive suffering including loss of initiative, appetite and vigilance.	1.9835656498705316
It reduces life-quality, often accompanied by depressive moods.	2.2624158147539704
Acute pain causes changes in the central nervous system leading to an increased sensitivity of nociception (hyperalgesia).	2.49619967607396
During healing, the central processing of noxious stimuli is normalised taking minutes to weeks.	2.0577300260706477
Sometimes, unknown factors initiate chronification of pain.	2.1805665248712547
Changes on a molecular level in peripheral tissue as well as in the central nervous system induce "cellular early genes" [24], a synthesis of c-fos, c-jun and other proteins favouring the chronification of pain.	2.0132035180911947
All efforts have to be made to depress or interrupt such a development.	2.462986207048501
One of the first steps to pain prophylaxis in a hospital is an optimal surgical technique: incision, extension, limited tissue damage and minimal invasive surgery should guarantee the smallest impairment of the nociceptive system possible.	1.9854333917338813
However, nociceptive input is intense and of long duration and leads to central sensibilisation.	2.093034036813231
Postoperative pain has lost its function as surgery anticipates healing.	2.166457363773754
Pain induces a reduction of ventilation, circulation, digestion and increases the risk of other disorders.	2.5308043803677656
There is need of aggressive pain treatment for humanitarian reasons and for reasons of late sequelae like permanent pain and increased reduction of function [10].	1.9176468032027019
This is of pivotal importance in patients with amputations or sympathetic reflex dystrophy (SRD).	2.3284431225723985
Antinociception is best provided by regional anaesthesia technique with a combination of local anaesthetics and opioids which results in better outcome [2, 12].	2.2100330995469695
Hence, regional anaesthesia techniques are strongly indicated in those patients.	2.3469506106339875
Good antinociception may be even more important than it is assumed today.	2.203181656946069
Anand [1] demonstrated a lower morbidity and mortality in 45 newborns undergoing cardiothoracic surgery, when general anaesthesia was performed with high-dose sufentanil versus halothane supplementary doses of morphine.	2.2568357179608785
Anaesthesiologists have to reconsider the quality of general anaesthesia: the antinociception of their regimen.	2.4856526981777756

Refering to a three-step-scheme that makes difference in the diagnostics in I. non-invasive, II.	2.301087057126992
invasive procedures the current diagnostic measures will be explained.	2.508207767431635
To the non-invasive measures do account the extensive patients history taking including the sexual history and the psychological diagnostics, the physical examination and laboratory screenings.	2.118843171936743

The procedures of this step are essentially limited to patients with erectile dysfunction who are planned for surgical interventions.	2.1195920920743916
Technological advances in the last two years in mammalian nuclear transfer techniques and the establishment of human embryonic stem cell lines formed the background of the International Workshop on "Embryonic Stem Cells and Nuclear Transfer Strategies" organized at the Gene Center, Munich, September 1999.	1.933775595071756
The aim of the meeting was to bring together scientists working in the stem cell field and those working on somatic nuclear transfer techniques to discuss the present status and prospects of both technologies for basic and applied research and future use in medicine and livestock breeding.	1.7356256248936732
"Biology of Embryonic Stem Cells", "Nuclear Transfer Strategies", and "Stem Cell Differentiation - Cell Therapy" were the main topics of the meeting.	1.8546328197329758
It became clear that we are far from understanding the processes involved in stem cell self-renewal and differentiation and the mechanisms resulting in reprogramming of nuclei from somatic cells after transfer into enucleated oocytes.	1.74381640979036
However, data were presented that showed the enormous potential of the embryonic stem cell technology for tissue transplantation in the future.	2.0476367105701287
Before any use of this technology in combination with any cloning technology for human cell therapy will be possible, further research including animal models and stem cell differentiation approaches in culture (i. e., identification of differentiation factors, selective differentiation strategies, reporter gene assays) is necessary to understand the basic principles of pluripotent stem cell differentiation and the mechanisms involved in reprogramming somatic cell nuclei.	1.9625643936832127
Certain fractures and/or dislocations of the femoral head are known to cause arterial injury and result in post-traumatic osteonecrosis.	2.7337272001048687

The aim of our study was to investigate the influence that serum of patients with preeclampsia has on t-PA and PAI-1 expression from human endothelial cells.	2.05344738692099
For this purpose, we cultured human endothelium cells, gained from umbilical veins, for 24 h with sera of 7 patients with HELLP syndrome and 12 patients with preeclampsia.	2.0522011864818563
The sera of 12 normotensive pregnant patients and 9 non-pregnant women were used as controls.	2.0793519010010075
We then determined t-PA and PAI-1 levels by ELISA, both in the maternal serum and in the supernatant of the endothelial cell cultures.	2.0822755359222618
While t-PA levels were significantly higher in the serum of patients with preeclampsia and HELLP syndrome than in the control group (median: 8.0 ng/ml and 6.2 ng/ml vs 3.9 ng/ml and 3.1 ng/ml), levels of PAI-1 did not show any significant disparity among the different groups.	2.354232830430899
The supernatant of the endothelial cell cultures demonstrated significantly elevated levels of both t-PA (P<0.001) and PAI-1 (P<0.01) when stimulated with serum gained from patients with preeclampsia or HELLP syndrome.	2.163362276078394
The increased expression of t-PA and PAI-1 from human endothelium cells after stimulation with the serum of preeclamptic patients must be considered as a sign of increased endothelial cell activation.	2.079766723429005
Postoperative pain relief can be achieved by several methods, including the use of systemic opioids and regional anaesthesia with intrathecal or epidural opioids or local anaesthetics.	2.3918390118758386
On-demand analgesia using a PCA (patient-controlled analgesia) system is regarded as the ideal option for systemic opioid analgesia.	2.0983959449815033
While PCA devices are not yet commonly used in all recovery units, the use of repetitive boluses on demand is still the most frequent form of administration in postoperative pain therapy.	2.371351083047641
In a study under double-blind conditions 135 ASA I and II patients were assigned at random to group I (infusion group) or group B (bolus group) when they first requested pain treatment after abdominal surgery.	1.963091999208966
The patients in group I received an initial intravenous loading dose of 100 mg tramadol, followed by an infusion of 12 mg/h tramadol for 24 h; if necessary, repeated boluses of 50 mg tramadol were given.	2.142041415943541
In group B the patients received a placebo infusion instead of the tramadol infusion; otherwise, the procedure was the same.	2.279077438970092
Pain relief was monitored by means of a VAS (visual analogue scale) up to 6 h after surgery.	2.333266341850568
We investigated the retrograde assessment of analgesia by the patients after 6 h, how often repetitive boluses were required, and the amount of analgesics administered in 6 and 24 h. Results.	2.361673150320017
The pain relief was assessed as excellent or good by 76.5% of group I and 65.6% of group B; 19.1% of group I and 26.9% of group B assessed the analgesic effect as satisfactory; 4.4% of group I and 7.5% of group B complained of insufficient analgesia.	1.9331587507093935
In group I 69.2% requested only one or no repetitive bolus, compared with 40.3% in group B, while two or more boluses were demanded by 30.8% in group I and 59.7% in group B.	2.0147662442664105
The average analgesic consumption after 6 h was 223.5 +/- 53.7 mg tramadol in group I and 176.6 +/- 63.1 mg tramadol in group B, respectively.	2.05410255157735
While the consumption during the first 6 h was comparable, from then on the consumption in group I increased significantly.	2.3998975710061767
Side effects were reported by 25% in both groups.	2.358070923912282
They were clinically irrelevant and did not necessitate termination of the clinical trial in any case.	2.422022500743974
During the study period pulse and blood pressure remained within the normal range and did not show any significant changes.	2.241884404748053
The fact that the patients in group I requested far fewer repetitive boluses than those in group B and the assessment by the patients led to the conclusion that treatment in the infusion group is better than that in the bolus group.	2.527077295203193
Concerns that a significantly higher consumption of analgesics would cause unwanted side-effects have proven unfounded.	2.3202298030315323
Six hours after surgery, when analgesia was evaluated by the patients, there was no significant difference between the two groups.	2.8806987974048504
Not until the maintenance infusion had been administered for a further 18 h, was the tramadol consumption within the infusion group significantly higher.	2.0881786462874565
Thus, we should consider continuing unreduced administration of the maintenance infusion 6 h after operation.	2.1505722710687607
The concept of tuberculid was introduced by Darier in 1896.	2.032413529457029
In contrast to "true" cutaneous tuberculosis, properties of the tuberculids were explained by an hyperergic response to myobacteria or their fragments released from a different site of manifest or passed tuberculous infection.	1.7892683030319094
Key features include a strongly positive tuberculin skin test, evidence of concomitant manifest or past tuberculosis, and prompt response to antituberculous therapy The inability to culture M. tuberculosis or to demonstrate it microscopically from lesional biopsies, together with reports on tuberculid-like eruptions after BCG vaccination, supports this concept.	1.6683920898627866
Clinical manifestations are lichen scrophulosorum, papulo-necrotic tuberculids and erythema induratum of Bazin.	1.8721864969541944
The existence of tuberculids has been questioned, however, because the clinical and histological appearances are not always specific.	2.911741619853615
An increasing number of case reports on tuberculids, new immunological tests and molecular biology-based techniques for the detection of mycobacteria have shed new light on the tuberculid concept.	2.0359857884530768

Treatment was successful with the protocol as proposed by the international study for children.	2.2220567165585345
This treatment is characterized by higher dosage and combination with 6-mercaptopurine.	2.5793732192668632
The prognosis of patients with malignant diseases requiring treatment on intensive care units is poor.	2.6364554041344874
The hospital mortality for mechanically ventilated patients ranges from 70-90% in patients with solid tumors to 75-90% in patients with hematological malignancy and up to 95% in patients after bone marrow transplantation.	2.3600172500771923
The number of patients referred to intensive care units is however increasing, due to improvements in the general treatment of malignant diseases.	2.4546574772548126
This results in controversies about the utilization of intensive care treatment in these patients.	2.2952781839487666
Since the individual outcome can not be predicted prior to initiation of intensive care therapy a general refusal of intensive care treatment seems not justified.	2.2002475374630133
A reevaluation of the patients status after initiation of intensive care treatment based on predefined criteria may however be useful in the decision about continuing intensive care measures.	2.403413412975805
Patients requiring mechanical ventilation after bone marrow transplantation will not survive if prolonged treatment with vasopressors is necessary and/or sustained hepatic and renal failure is present.	2.1172573743475023
Intensive care treatment should be continued in patients not fulfilling these criteria and treatment results are comparable to those in patients without malignant diseases.	2.2619575372106837
For other patients with malignant diseases the use of a new score system developed for patients with cancer can be helpful in the clinical decision making.	2.797929871037705
On the basis of a solution-oriented marital therapy, the different within-session effects of four different types of questions in systemic therapy (lineal, strategic, circular, and reflexive), as described by Tomm (1989), were tested.	1.927023847446819
In this single case study, the method of plan analysis (Caspar 1989) was used to categorize the client's reactions to the four types of therapeutic questions.	2.2889885218734083
the client, the clients' interaction, and the therapeutic interaction), whereas circular and reflexive questions were expected to open the system for change.	2.330612846048991
Interestingly this hypothesis was only supported for the wife, who had the role of the identified client in the therapy and demonstrated a much stronger motivation for change.	2.1912813559050064
For the husband, who preferred the role of a cotherapist and demonstrated only little motivation for change, results were not as predicted.	2.090657815427199
Some of his reactions were even opposite to the expected therapeutic effects.	2.1873231715083814
Prerequisites for experimental study designs are extremely difficult to realise under prehospital emergency conditions.	2.0219968265871575
Results obtained in animal experiments always need validation with prehospital or inhospital patient studies.	2.029572958959145
Investigations related to emergency medicine are, however, an ethical obligation on behalf of the patient.	2.460404277528929
A retrospective analysis of the available literature should be considered a prerequisite for prospective randomised and controlled studies.	2.8675819647621323
Frequently, a pilot study or feasibility trial needs to precede the actual study.	2.106661298713083
Informed consent must be obtained for all patient studies.	2.296873046837741
However, under emergency conditions informed consent cannot always be obtained due to unconsciousness, etc.	2.0327102353645508
Nevertheless, the following principles should be observed: (a) randomised studies are essential, even in emergency medicine; (b) they are ethically acceptable if the treatment provided for the study group is at least equivalent to the therapy for the control group; ( c) only these preconditions guarantee that the patient always receives treatment in accordance with the standard of treatment.	2.217426415714184
If the patient is unconscious or otherwise unable to give informed consent, the principle of deferred consent is acceptable.	2.1178783084052983
The deferred consent principle should be carefully documented.	2.3892895392448854
A prospective randomized study represents the gold standard for an investigation, even under emergency conditions.	2.2600991141611866
There are different principles of randomization: telephone or telefax randomisation, etc.	2.0658848195591952
Emergency medicine investigations need to be completed within a reasonable time frame which should, as a rule, not exceed 2 years.	2.2376866785677194
Otherwise, too many items might change without being noted.	2.1244432684727332
Curative treatment and the intention to treat are terms employed by ethics committees.	2.245430172563326
If an investigation does not bear in itself additional risk factors, it does not necessarily have to be brought before the ethics committee.	2.337861224439601
If, however, for example, the effect of obtaining blood samples is investigated separately for research purposes, the patient needs to be informed and sign the respective agreement.	2.638865432936626
In Germany the ethics committees have agreed to accept their respective decisions.	2.075092843803535
For multicentre and multinational studies, however, the ethics committees also need to accept decisions made by non-German ethics committees.	2.2070635634546125
Not all therapeutic principles can serve as the basis of prospective randomized studies because they need to be considered the present standard of care (e.g., endotracheal intubation, etc.).	2.5184584064462125
Nevertheless, the feasibility of a study should be assessed according to the 1-3 rating proposed by the American Heart Association.	2.441789621130217
In principle, the overall emergency physician protocol does not fulfill scientific requirements.	2.0822635655049218
Scores can be of importance for investigating different treatment regimens.	2.4379856810523406
Biases in emergency medicine studies focus on the variability of EMS, personnel qualifications, etc.	2.319978316532388
This is in part why it is extremely difficult to prove efficacy and efficiency in emergency medicine.	2.1234076982386325
The results of emergency medicine investigations should be published in suitable journals, i.e., journals with a reasonable rating.	2.0269506706309977

Nevertheless, in daily practice the failure rate is 20-30% both with itraconazole and terbinafine.	2.153888848371316
In our investigations for the fungicidal effects of terbinafine, we could show that the same strain of Trichophyton rubrum or T. mentagrophytes in the rest period needs 1000 times higher concentration of terbinafine (2,0 to 0,002 µg/ml) for complete fungal killing as in the growth phase.	1.902799019976914

The acute liver failure (ALF) is a complex syndrome resulting from loss of synthetic and metabolic functions of the liver.	2.287706911602716
Despite recent advances in intensive care medicine patients with severe ALF have a very high mortality and the orthotopic liver transplantation still remains the only proven effective treatment of ALF.	2.324094361168855
Numerous attempts have been made to improve survival by using various extracorporeal support techniques, but none of these therapeutic approaches was able to increase the survival rate.	2.2713185987607574
Liver support systems based on detoxification procedures only could not influence the deleterious course of the disease.	2.0045894250967216
It is certain that an ideal liver support system should be capable to fulfil the liver's essential synthetic and metabolic functions as well as detoxification and excretion.	2.049919796096588
Over the last years the development of hybrid liver assist devices has aimed at replacing these liver functions and therefore might give an advantage over earlier systems based on detoxification techniques only.	1.9755791391093016
This article gives a short review of the various liver support systems and focuses then on the hybrid liver support systems, their construction and the remaining problems after the first clinical applications.	2.2114644987937946
After a latency period of 20 years, in a 39-year-old Austrian citizen of Chinese origin, a surgically removed rectal carcinoma, as well as the neighboring chronic inflammatory rectal mucosa with various degrees of dysplasia and one positive neighboring lymph node, showed helminthiasis in the histopathological examination, convincing us of a link between carcinoma and chronic helminthiasis.	1.93342886202857
Whereas the etiological context between chronic infection by Schistosoma haematobium and endemic frequent urinary bladder carcinoma is considered a matter of fact, whether of not the incidence of intestinal carcinoma is increased in connection with chronic intestinal schistosomiasis is controversial.	1.985859715391764
The etiological and pathogenetic link between helminthiasis and carcinoma should be considered in the same way as for other related inflammatory large-bowel diseases.	2.0846321359962965
In the sequence chronic inflammation - severe dysplasia, the formation of carcinoma could possibly occur.	2.0580835658577845
Besides a survey of trematodes parasitology and pathology, the link between rectal carcinoma and Schistosomiasis japonicum is pointed out by means of appropriate literature investigations.	2.13130070955019
Rupture of the carotid artery wall is a very rare postoperative complication.	2.452506342890728
Mainly ruptures of vein patches are described in the literature.	2.3137515335582726
This paper reports on a 51-year-old patient with elective endarterectomy of the left internal carotid artery using V-Y technique.	2.3463070177860845
On day 8 after operation, the carotid bulb ruptured.	2.403128582457381
The rupture was due to local wall necrosis, as verified by histologic examination.	2.24416208840931
In an emergency procedure the necrotized tissue was resected and repaired using a Dacron patch.	2.062211408281014
Myocardial stunning (contractile dysfunction in the presence of normalized perfusion) and myocardial hibernation (contractile dysfunction matching reduced perfusion) have represented separate concepts of viable, but dyssynergic myocardium in the past.	1.987119085399656
However, in vivo experimental and clinical work suggests that repetitive ischemia due to coronary artery disease may induce a gradual transition between stunned and hibernating myocardium.	1.9954526455373436
Myocardial hibernation itself can result from a spectrum of ischemic conditions ranging from impaired myocardial blood flow reserve to frank hypoperfusion.	1.9614626003991338
With increasing severity and duration of ischemia, degeneration of cardiac myocytes, accumulation of glycogen and cell death ensue.	2.091802346544119
Additonally, there is an increase of extracellular matrix protein content leading to reparative fibrosis, which in turn limits functional recovery.	2.4442969524322202
In the light of these structural features, the available methods for detection of viable myocardium, in particular dobutamine echocardiography and nuclear imaging techniques, offer complementary rather than contradictory information.	2.0014385886889237
Dobutamine echo has satisfactory sensitivity, excellent specificity, and high diagnostic accuracy for the detection of viable dyssynergic myocardium.	2.223739692393552
While in the past only its predictive accuracy for segmental recovery has been validated, newer data show an improved survival after revascularization if at least four viable dyssynergic left ventricular segments in a 16 segment model can be identified by dobutamine echocardiography.	1.7491555052605394
The complete (low and high dose) dobutamine protocol can elicit several types of contractile responses (sustained improvement in contraction or monophasic response, biphasic response, new wall motion abnormality) which should be interpreted in view of other clinical data including a previous infarction.	1.8049931392885816
If ischemia or viability is documented, revascularization should be performed promptly.	2.4048767624583984
A similar strategy should be followed in the setting of chronic coronary heart disease with left ventricular dysfunction.	2.320082388159536
Since the structural changes of hibernating myocardium are progressive, time to revascularization is critical.	2.0839770226450813
On the other hand, responsible therapeutic planning requires proof of ischemia or viability before initiating a potentially hazardous revascularization procedure.	1.764003363677609
The coarctation of the aorta is a congenital narrowing of the aorta in the transitional area between the distal aortic arch and the proximal descending aorta.	2.1791383095238617
The coarctation causes an arterial hypertension of the upper half and an arterial hypotension of the lower half of the body.	2.632385717658129
The indication for operative repair is given because of the hypertension with strain and possible insufficiency of the heart.	2.3134524981005775
The resection of the narrowed part of the aorta with end-to-end anastomosis or interposition of a prosthesis brings on the risk of a recoarctation.	2.637021012977713
After a Vosschulte-aortoplasty a recurrent coarctation is rarely seen.	2.1681630785036474
This method, however, brings on a higher risk of the development of an aneurysm.	3.2900323865196746

Successful transplantation of autologous chondrocytes for repair of articular cartilage defects requires an undisturbed matrix-synthesis of the transplanted cells.	2.120201019787974
This, in turn, is dependent on the composition of the synovial fluid (SF) of the respective joint.	2.5239018567407343
We addressed the question whether analysis of a patient's SF can predict the rate of matrix-synthesis of articular cartilage exposed to this SF in vitro.	2.2884360762844844
SF was obtained from 115 patients with disorders of the knee, including gonarthrosis (n = 44), meniscal tears (n = 10), rheumatoid arthritis (n = 53), and reactive arthritides (n = 8).	2.4208942504635607
In the SF, the following parameters were determined: Interleukin-1, IL-6, IL-8, IL-1-RA, TNF, Insulin-like growth-factor I (IGF-I), IGF-II, IGF-binding protein-2 (IGFBP-2), IGFBP-3 as well as total proteinase activity and total collagenase activity.	2.483877166652931
In some cases, a monoclonal antibody directed against IGF-I was added.	2.3295541212018485
SF from patients with OA or trauma, respectively, stimulated PG-synthesis of bovine cartilage more markedly than did SF from patients with rheumatic arthritides.	2.077159127407282
On the average, 60 percent of the SF-induced increase of cartilage matrix synthesis could be titrated out by an anti-IGF-I-AB.	2.050415515606262
The best predictor for the SF-effects on PG-synthesis of exposed cartilage was the proportion of free IGF-I (r = 0.573, p < 0.001, Spearman rank correlation) followed by the SF-concentrations of IGF-I (with a positive sign), IGFBP-3, IL-1, and TNF (all with a negative sign).	2.06532385975638
According to our data, IGF-I is the most important anabolic factor in human SF with respect to cartilage PG-synthesis.	2.6119650325946524
The proportion of free IGF-I seems to be of special importance in this regard.	2.5596758386936758
Low SF-levels of free IGF-I could be identified as a possible risk-factor for a sub-optimal protoeglycan synthesis of chondrocytes exposed to this synovial milieu.	2.157830990793677

However, only few studies investigated the coincidence of panic disorder with schizophrenia.	2.1692511009618696
This may in part be explained by the fact that both positive and negative symptoms of schizophrenia may mask the clinical symptoms of a panic disorder.	2.237451211155289

In those children with birth weight below 2500 g the incidence was 6.8 permil.	2.0607293177916604
In 17 of 18 cases the cause of anemia could be clarified.	2.402869143336188
In five preterm babies (28%) an acute fetofetal transfusion and in three newborns a fetomaternal transfusion was responsible for the onset of anemia.	2.138544635623188
In two cases there was Rh incompatibility, in two cases placental bleeding, and in another two cases fetal tumour bleeding caused the anemia.	2.2312597725975847
In one fully developed newborn there was severe disseminated intestinal bleeding of unknown cause.	1.9651012641438648
Another child suffered from EBV infection, and one had trisomy 13 with multiple malformations.	2.307678267903145
Ten children (55%) had to be resuscitated due to hypovolemic shock.	2.4647382753371394
Fifteen children were intubated and ventilated mechanically.	2.366884918168478

Five of these seven children had to be resuscitated at birth.	2.435491042710016

Five children (28%) including three full-term babies were developed normally.	2.1867487735546605
In conclusion, severe anemia with hemoglobin below 10 g/dl is very rare but serious.	2.103770075387852

PCT appears to have several advantages; it is of non-hepatic (yet unknown) origin and useful in patients with hepatic insufficiency.	2.3910807007099297

Results: 78 patients (39 willow bark extract, 39 placebo) participated in the trial.	2.1688240376915746

Recently, new insights into the phenomenology of transient cerebral hypoxia have been gained from video analysis of experimentally induced syncope.	1.8949419877922724
Common elements of syncope include multifocal and generalized myoclonus, tonic body extension, automatisms, vocalizations, eye deviations and hallucinations.	1.7377890663000655
Thus, it is not the presence or absence of these features but their specific character that distinguishes syncope from epileptic seizures.	2.1274014096286664
Other clues for differential diagnosis include precipitating factors, premonitory symptoms and postictal events, such as tongue bites and postictal confusion, which has been identified as the single most powerful factor discriminating syncope from epileptic seizures.	2.0013846133505684
In contrast, incontinence and head injury are common in both conditions.	2.109556454107896
Investigations such as electroencephalogram, tilt testing and postictal prolactin or creatine kinase levels may aid diagnosis but are never diagnostic in isolation.	1.7626984552775204
In rare cases, hypoxic and epileptic mechanisms may interact within one attack.	1.989536802625762

The compartment syndrome (cs) is characterized by an increased tissue pressure in a limited space.	2.390944058717004
Pathophysiologically, it is a multifactorial disease that is potentially induced by an initial trauma and develops according to the existence of cofactors.	2.5136731631935385
Cofactors are, for instance, the circulation of the patient and the initial treatment of the impending cs.	2.824713422546689
In particular, the microcirculation is altered with endothelial destruction, development of a capillary leak, protein loss from intravasal space and the development of an interstitial and intracellular third space.	2.0254322858090275
An impaired drainage of the lymphatic and venous system causes a venous infarction.	2.2070611942078195
An arterial infarction results if the tissue pressure exceeds the arteriolar pressure.	2.048520928608788
An accompanying ischemia reperfusion mechanism increases the trauma load.	2.2052740114841116
In disadvantageous cases, the patients are in danger of developing a multi-organ deficiency syndrome (MODS) by an uncontrolled inflammatory reaction, by intravasal volume loss and by a myonephropathic systemic reaction.	2.0863132875024766
Clinically, the patients suffer a disproportionate amount of pain, followed by neurological signs.	2.4285706903546664
Especially in noncompliant patients, tissue pressure measurement is useful.	2.2530334946934105
Resuscitation of the circulation as well as splitting of casts is important.	2.8684504217107976
In case of a manifest cs, dermatofasciotomy has to be performed as an emergency operation.	3.0138231274424787
Even if cs is diagnosed early and fasciotomy is carried out early, the development of sequellae cannot be avoided in every single case.	2.194432956403906

There were 165 cases of blunt trauma and 13 cases of penetrating injury.	2.135858949115955
110 cases were classified as simple injuries (grade I or II) and 68 cases as complex injuries (grade III to V).	2.2222050965148825
The overall mortality was 32 % (57 patients).	2.2013199373012866
The mortality for true hepatic injury was 15.7 %.	2.2267548159155632
None of the patients with penetrating injuries died.	2.743564000877078

Intraabdominal abscess formation was seen in 2.8 %.	2.7973967180504578
Operative therapy for liver injuries depends on the grade of the injury.	2.684732597474585

Urine specimens were collected from 49 persons up to 10 days after abstaining from cannabis use.	2.1918900971982787
Urine samples (n = 135) were investigated for free and conjugated 9-carboxy-11-nor tetrahydrocannabinol (THCCOOH) by LC/MS/MS and for free and glucuronidated tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) and 11-hydroxy-THC (11-OH-THC) by GC/MS prior to and after enzyme hydrolysis.	1.822855722531769
Concentrations for free and conjugated THCCOOH were measured with reference to 100 mg creatinine/dL urine.	2.188039069323906
Cannabis use was classified as light, moderate and heavy according to the current literature.	2.6650902878190443
In all groups chosen free and bound THCCOOH was present in urine samples on the day of the last use and on the next day.	2.2885184496304207
Urine samples from occasional and frequent users generally differed in the amount of THCCOOH and THCCOOH glucuronide.	2.0795919896337636
Within 4-6 days the concentrations of free and glucuronidated THCCOOH in urine samples of heavy users decreased to those ranges present in urine samples of moderate and light users.	2.0062488334428235
In frequent users, THC glucuronide and 11-OH-THC glucuronide could be found up to 1 and 3 days after abstinence, respectively.	2.077177167951537
In light users, neither THC glucuronide nor 11-OH-THC glucuronide was detectable.	1.9295887171986401
The determination of conjugated THC and 11-OH-THC in addition to free and bound THCCOOH is suggested as an aid in assessing the frequency of cannabis use, but is limited to samples obtained within a few days after the last consumption.	2.18573203954381

Using 8 different monoclonal antibodies, immunohistology was performed on 36 follicular adenomas and on 28 follicular, 34 papillary, 27 medullary and 29 anaplastic carcinomas of the thyroid.	1.95715147020534
The panel of antibodies was directed against broad-spectrum cytokeratins (pan-CK, antibody lu-5), against basic and acid high-molecular-weight CK of types  1, 5, 10 and 14, against basic ( 5 and 6) and acid high-molecular-weight CK ( 13) and against basic ( 7 and  8) and acid low-molecular-weight CK ( 19 and  20).	1.8925887153355814
With the exception of a large number of anaplastic carcinomas, nearly all other tumours exhibited strong immunoreactivity with antibodies against pan-CK, CK 8 and CK 19.	1.8774596299122417
CK 20 expression was exclusively shown for 2 medullary carcinomas.	2.2368842242305327
Reactivity for high-molecular-weight CK could only, each time focally, be demonstrated for 14 papillary and 2 follicular carcinomas and for 2 anaplastic carcinomas with partial squamous differentiation.	1.8975606250493027
Thirteen anaplastic carcinomas were not decorated by any of the CK antibodies applied.	2.1994122310795916
CK 7 staining exceeding the staining of individual cells was observed in 26 papillary cancers.	2.2821284030513542
In contrast, such a finding could only be obtained with each one follicular adenoma, medullary carcinoma and anaplastic carcinoma and with 5 follicular carcinomas.	2.0400076901281228

New is the finding that there exist considerable differences between papillary carcinomas and all other non-papillary thyroid tumours regarding CK 7 expression.	1.9260314427766223

Tumor invasion of the portal vein by ductal adenocarcinoma of the pancreatic head is classically known as a criterion for inoperability.	2.1143684254143875
Despite improvement in operation techniques for portal vein resection during Whipple's procedure and acceptable mortality and morbidity, in the case of uncertain tumor infiltration vascular resection cannot be recommended in general.	2.112401363365854
The problem is the preoperative detection of tumor infiltration of the portal vein.	2.4127076870520443
Often the surgeon is confronted with unsuspected macroscopic portal vein infiltration or tumor adhesion during the operation.	2.0424391541144145
Between 1986 and 1995 105 patients underwent Whipple's procedure for ductal adenocarcinoma of the pancreatic head in our department.	1.96761933393115
In eight of these cases partial portal vein resection was performed because of macroscopic tumor infiltration or tumor adhesion.	2.235353650098535
In four of the eight cases histological tumor infiltration of all vascular layers was found.	2.0926815280794537
In the others we found no or only adventitial tumor invasion.	2.1907382356828715
The patients without tumor infiltration of the portal vein showed a survival time after surgery of 27.78 months in contrast to 6.67 months in the group with histologically proven tumor infiltration.	2.228864224664136
Endovascular, intraportal ultrasound (IPEUS), a new diagnostic procedure, can give helpful information regarding portal vein involvement.	2.253020416776278
Although the IPEUS is not a standard diagnostic procedure it was shown to detect portal vein infiltration with high sensitivity and specificity.	2.3603691895969994

In all three subtests including odor identification, odor detection threshold, and odor discrimination, the control group scored significantly better than the IPS group, yielding a specificity and sensitivity of 90% each.	1.8689621586052831

Toxic metabolic and immunologic products in the serum have been discussed as possible causes.	2.278119033588058
For this reason we have performed plasmapheresis on these patients for many years.	2.1215849113065963
Results regarding survival and healing of the lesions are quite favorable, as exemplified with two patients described here who benefited from the procedure despite their old age.	1.981634387886746

The most recent diagnostic advances comprise noninvasive tissue characterization of the aortic wall, immunofluorescence studies or pulse chase analyses of skin and cultured dermal fibroblasts, and molecular analysis at the cDNA/DNA level of the fibrillin-1 gene.	1.846722557850177

Primary defects of skeletal growth and development can be subdivided into hypoplasias, dysostoses and dysplasias.	2.0033518501514167
Hypoplastic bones are small but otherwise normal.	2.3641513485247456
Generalized skeletal hypoplasias comprise various forms of primordial dwarfism and syndromal disorders including trisomy 21 and Ullrich-Turner syndrome.	1.7989896805370478
Dysostoses are defects of bones as organs resulting from errors of morphogenesis.	2.1092820099505625
Many of them are caused by mutations of single genes in the cascade of morphogenetic gene sequences.	2.1785460939719252
Dysplasias are defects of bone as tissue.	2.4690106415156396
Some of them (e. g. achondroplasia, Jansen type of metaphyseal chondrodysplasia) are caused by defects of signal genes influencing cell division or differentiation.	1.92235443508106
Others result from gene mutations affecting the cellular production of matrix components.	2.0986700446832742
Examples are collagenopathies such as osteogenesis imperfecta and some spondyloepiphyseal dysplasias.	1.9917892930001537
Finally, disorders such as pycnodysostosis, result from defects of chondro-osseous homeostasis.	1.9987040692037883
The study of skeletal defects helps to unravel the complexity of normal skeletal development.	2.0604119577054028
Human parvovirus B19 causes erythema infectiosum (fifth disease) and aplastic crisis.	1.9709908748706388
In pregnancy, B19 may be transmitted on to the fetus resulting in hydrops fetalis.	2.0909428293961394
B19 is sometimes associated with thrombocytopenia and vasculitis.	2.2875089303896523
In immunocompromised patients, B19 may persist causing chronic infection.	2.27774514563824
Several methods for detecting B19 virus or specific antibodies are now available.	2.1032759715129625
B19 infection does not usually require therapy.	2.4142133591637562
Efficacy of immunoglobulins in chronic B19 infection has been demonstrated.	2.567121075812621
In absence of significant symptoms and signs, the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism (PE) remains difficult.	2.5883260399326837
Sensitivity and specifity of laboratory tests, chest X-ray, and ECG on their own is low.	2.303271595639279
Echocardiography is particularly useful in critically ill patients suspected of having pulmonary emboli and can help identify right ventricular pressure overload.	2.1591351210360905
Venous ultrasonography is useful in patients with suspected PE, but normal results do not rule out PE.	2.456281487483859
Helical CT with contrast medium can identify pulmonary emboli.	2.3833294854688987
However, if the CT findings are normal in the presence of a high index of clinical suspicion, only larger pulmonary embolism are ruled out, and angiography with the focus on distal pulmonary vasculature should be performed.	2.11945470505882
The diagnosis of pulmonary embolism should be made by combining clinical assessment, several diagnostic techniques, and finally pulmonary angiography in doubtful cases.	2.1549183378270333
Heparin remains the standard therapy for patients with stable hemodynamics.	3.080367489208966
Thrombolytic therapy is recommended in hemodynamically compromised patients.	2.6003204858516487
In short-term dose regimes, the thrombolytic agents urokinase, streptokinase, and rt-PA seem to be equally efficient.	2.268551616859744
So far, however, no study has proven that thrombolytic therapy significantly reduces mortality in pulmonary embolism.	2.281700840322564

Renal tubular dysgenesis is a rarely recognized condition characterized by oligohydramnios, Potter's sequence and congenital anuria leading to stillbirth or neonatal death from respiratory failure.	1.7379813402471331
It is thought to be inherited in an autosomal recessive manner.	2.387567381956259
Definitive diagnosis is based on renal histology, revealing the lack of proximal tubule differentiation.	2.567203962771724
Lectin and immunohistochemical studies confirmed structural and functional immaturity of the proximal tubule.	2.410323093715768
Further findings include bilateral renal vein thrombosis.	2.3193038405662363
The clinical and morphological parameters defining this disorder and the possible mechanisms of pathogenesis are discussed.	2.1197065033208995
Articular cartilage has only a small capacity for regneration.	2.417139982983793
This makes the repair of articular surfaces difficult.	2.451037909004369
In 1959 Pridie described his method of resurfacing osteoarthritic knee joints.	2.0397585822894517
This operation is still in widespread use today.	2.4070564874138562
Pridie introduced the principle of drilling exposed subchondral bone with the objective of encouraging a fibro-cartilaginous repair.	2.0352338068343205
The newly formed fibrocartilaginous layer that develops over the lesion in osteoarthritis may be enough to decrease patients symptoms.	1.955773266540529
Bone drilling into the subchondral layer is also effective in promoting healing of osteochondrosis dissecans.	2.0674753993366917
The choice of the treatment should be based on factors such as age of the patient, serverity of symptoms, activity level and functional demands on the joint, site and stage of the lesion.	2.681390756676719
The drilling operation remains useful in osteoathritis and osteochondrosis dissecans.	2.060507958831835
Recent immunobiological findings together with advances in biotechnology, ameliorations in clinical trial design, and MRI developments have led to a variety of therapeutical approaches in multiple sclerosis (MS).	2.076949747798642
However, in contrast to successfully introduced new treatments, a number of therapeutical failures exist as well: despite impressive data from animal models, convincing concepts, and promising phase I/II studies, some investigated drugs and strategies showed no positive effects in clinical trials, or trials had to be terminated because of unexpected side effects.	1.911243679294443
This article provides an overview of clinical studies that have failed or been abandoned for other reasons.	2.1574820664502496
Tumor necrosis factor (TNF) -antagonists which have led to negative effects in two studies (Lenercept, Infliximab) are discussed in detail.	2.097376780503162
These results raise critical questions concerning the hypothetical pathogenesis of MS lesions and the value of MRI in the assessment of clinically relevant therapeutic drug effects.	2.2165268552397763
Isolated pancreatic metastases from renal-cell carcinomas (RCC) are extremely rare.	2.3001841531351173
Only 96 cases of clinically diagnosed renal-cell carcinoma metastatic to the pancreas have been reported in the world literature, and 70 of the patients (including ours) underwent a definitive surgical resection.	2.3411093810402286
In many cases the time between the nephrectomy and diagnosis of metachronous metastases is reported to exceed 10 years.	2.071618084261864
Therefore, the initial diagnosis may be overlooked when there is a prolonged disease-free interval.	2.61700331143386
When it does occur simultaneously or metachronously, aggressive surgical resection, when possible, seems to be the most effective treatment for this metastatic lesion.	2.2677250887435583
Surgical resection can provide long-term survival in selected cases.	2.5846056269548185
We present the case of a 69-year-old woman in whom two pancreatic metastases were treated by a left-sided subtotal pancreatectomy with splenectomy, 12 years after radical nephrectomy for a RCC.	2.1420509936118073
The patient simultaneously presented with both a mass in the body of the pancreas and a right-sided colon cancer.	2.286449112307248
Thus, the diagnosis of pancreatic metastasis of colon cancer was suspected initially.	2.5691208154317224
Both tumors were radically resected, and histological examination revealed two pancreatic metastases from the previous RCC.	2.2465700030642544
In the world literature this report represents the eighth case of multiple pancreatic metastases due to RCC.	2.0562456062057297
It illustrates a rare indication of pancreatic resection because of pancreatic metastasis.	2.206444048188623
The need for prolonged follow-up of patients is emphasized.	2.7669321978748056
The few reports on surgically treated pancreatic metastases from RCC are reviewed after the presentation of this case.	2.166919692887686
Delusion is understood to mean intersubjectively disconcerting convictions with a tendency toward subjective certainty that lose their disconcerting character when made the object of psychiatric analysis in the knowledge of their independence from mental disorder.	1.7883996579917119
The perceptions from which delusions arise are dynamically charged according to their role in the structural context.	2.2875467315260662
The realisation pressure that burdens the perceptions and is intensified in psychotic constitutions is a precondition for the delusion.	1.8115733243579077
The failure of derealisation brought about by the psychotic disorganisation of the structure is also a requirement.	2.1131044180551286
Based on a case study, considerations arising out of the initial stages of schizophrenic delusion are extended to other forms of delusion and to the conditions for chronification.	2.241526975447931
High-dose chemotherapy (HDCT) is a promising treatment for patients with germ cell tumours and a poor prognosis.	2.469638040273246
The selection of patients who may profit from this intervention is challenging for the urologist, as the indication has to be carefully established.	2.407786880754253
Exclusion criteria primarily concern impaired organ functions.	2.2913420281335957
Prior to HDCT haematopoietic stem cells are obtained after the administration of conventional-dose chemotherapy plus G- or GM-CSF stimulation.	2.0263099768937507
HDCT consists of a combination of carboplatin, etoposide and ifosfamide or cyclophosphamide.	2.4508986383633022
After HDCT, haematologic monitoring and maximal supportive care are essential.	2.0957784147144647
It is therefore recommended that HDCT only be administered at specialized centres.	2.0188235094984996
Pyoderma gangrenosum develops in most patients between the age of 25 and 54 years.	2.493307819885436
It usually occurs in otherwise healthy persons or in association with a systemic desease.	2.3908202160968544
Extremely painful ulcerations are characteristic and evolve rapidly.	2.2316746060071737
Malignant pyoderma, the variant described in our case report, is an aggressive variant of ulcerative pyoderma gangrenosum, rapidly progressive and a potentially lethal ulcerative disease.	2.0272635766030795
The diagnosis of pyoderma gangrenosum depends on recognition of the evolving clinical features because histopathologic changes are not specific and characteristically serological or hematological markers of the disease do not exist.	2.077663173680704
Histopathologic findings, however, always include vasculitis, either in form of the necrotizing cutaneous vasculitis (7), granulomatous (1) or lymphocytic vasculitis (2).	2.557245549758664
We report on a 36-year-old male patient, who underwent surgery for repair of an aneurysm of the aortic arch.	2.588436625924835
The aneurysm occurred two months after exacerbation of a malignant variant of pyoderma gangrenosum with nearly lethal exit.	2.171901769403021
An association of pyoderma gangrenosum with vasculitis has been described previously, but the present report is the first to describe an aortic arch aneurysm which seems to be associated with necrotizing angiitis of the vasa vasorum caused by a pyoderma gangrenosum.	2.3454107920049685

The main goal of the present biomechanical study in vitro was to demonstrate the different grades of instability in the correlation to progressive disko-ligamentous defects as well as stabilisation through dynamic and static procedures.	2.2449629855625743

Analysing 71 cases the indications and results of stereotactic neurosurgery are presented.	2.39609241878979
In 53 patients stereotactic serial biopsies of different intraaxial lesions were performed, in 5 patients a spontaneous haemorrhage of the basal ganglia was removed by lysis with r-tPA.	1.9861991010090385
In 3 patients suffering from hydrocephalus due to diencephalic cysts a cystventricular shunt device was implanted.	2.0763822802101504
In 3 patients an intracerebral abscess was aspirated and drained.	2.145787581437406

The accuracy of stereotactic tumour biopsies was 88.7 % in our series, in accordance to other authors.	2.0825297887068612

Radiotherapy of patients with prostate cancer offers an alternative to radical prostatectomy in early stages (T1-T2).	2.494567068906231
In locally advanced prostate cancer a high dose or combined radiotherapy is more effective than radical surgery with concurrent lower morbidity and mortality.	2.074318440205374
Recent developments in linear accellerator technique, the progress in dose calculation and planning techniques provide the means to apply higher doses to a given tumor volume while effectively protecting the surrounding normal tissue at the same time.	1.8191849246131029
These improvements may possibly reduce the rate of therapy related side effects or complications significantly.	2.354008124590547

In special cases with a very low risk of recurrent tumor an interstitial permanent brachytherapy alone is indicated.	2.4429363078929867

Skin is the second most common site of extranodal lymphoma.	2.2667124304547124
The significance of cutaneous B-cell lymphomas has been underestimated due to the lack of monoclonal antibodies and molecular genetics in former years.	2.2813181791615667
Cutaneous B-cell lymphomas represent a heterogenous group of entities which show variation in histology, immunophenotype and in prognosis.	1.9962995866752589
The most common entities presenting in skin are follicular lymphomas, marginal zone B-cell lymphomas, and diffuse large B-cell lymphomas.	1.954031408230237
The majority of primary cutaneous B-cell lymphomas have an excellent prognosis.	2.259156540514121
Whereas in B-cell lymphomas with secondary spread to the skin the clinical course is dependant on the prognosis of the primary lymphoma.	2.437155748318819
It is evident that primary cutaneous lymphomas are distinct from nodal lymphomas and not extranodal manifestations of their lymph-node-based counterparts.	1.9283560941936024
In the current review the morphologic spectrum of cutaneous B-cell lymphomas comprising primary and secondary cutaneous B-cell lymphomas is discussed according to the WHO classification sheme.	2.1709799738997066
The phencyclidine derivative ketamine is a non-competitive N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor antagonist with the thalamo-neocortical projection system as the primary site of action.	1.9167630549684813
Racemic ketamine consists of the enantiomers S(+)-ketamine and R(-)-ketamine.	2.226593203156169
Racemic ketamine has never been considered an adequate anaesthetic agent in neurosurgical patients since  it produces regionally specific stimulation of cerebral metabolism (CMRO2) and increases cerebral blood flow (CBF) and intracranial pressure (ICP).	1.8424716006636632
However, recent experiments suggest that both tracemic ketamine and S(+)-ketamine may reduce infarct size in animal models of incomplete cerebral ischaemia and brain injury.	1.9827214163831763
This experimental protective effect appears to be related to decreases in Ca++ influx and maintenance of brain tissue magnesium levels due to NMDA and quisqualate receptor blockade by ketamine.	1.9648667153658965
Studies in dogs have shown that racemic ketamine (2.0 mg/kg) increases CBF in the presence of the cerebral vasodilator N2O.	2.298815147846897
In contrast, studies in rats without background anaesthesia showed increases in CBF after racemic ketamine (100 mg/kg i.p.).	1.9869043505520354
This suggests that the cerebrovascular effects of racemic ketamine are related to the pre-existing cerebrovascular tone induced by background anaesthetics.	2.033973036455741
Cerebrovascular CO2 reactivity was maintained regardless of the baseline cerebrovascular resistance.	2.2433302513250926
There are several mechanisms by which racemic ketamine may increase CBF.	2.098947957842217
It induces dose-dependent respiratory depression with consequent mild hypercapnia in spontaneously ventilating subjects.	2.0333317401518487
This produces vasodilation due to the intact cerebrovascular CO2 reactivity.	2.615558556048308
Racemic ketamine also induces regional neuroexcitation, which leads to stimulation of cerebral glucose consumption in the limbic, extrapyramidal, auditory, and sensory-motor systems.	1.8364809984869572
This regional neuroexcitation with increased CMRO2 produces increases in CBF that can be blocked by infusion of barbiturates or benzodiazepines.	2.083721075577345
However, increases in CBF with racemic ketamine (1 mg/kg) may also occur during normocapnia and without changes in CMRO2.	2.3575193954976874
This effect is related to some additional direct cerebral vasodilating potency of racemic ketamine based on a mechanism involving blockade of Ca++ channels.	2.095009106022165
The effects of racemic ketamine on CBF autoregulation have not been investigated systematically.	2.2963486433304916
However, studies in rats have shown that CBF autoregulation was maintained with low- and high-dose S(+)-ketamine.	2.492362575467903
Infusion of racemic ketamine alters intracranial volume and ICP.	2.4328254477352744
Studies in spontaneously ventilating pigs with and without intracranial hypertension have shown that racemic ketamine (0.5-5.0 mg/kg) produces increases in PaCO2 and ICP.	2.1689825532295974
In contrast, identical experiments with mechanical ventilation and controlled PaCO2 showed no changes in ICP following racemic ketamine infusion.	1.9210996282501587
This implies that increases in ICP are related to inadequate ventilation with consecutive hypercapnia and increases in intracranial blood volume.	2.0050665545571134
However, mechanical ventilation may not be sufficient to control ICP following racemic ketamine.	2.2875723491205178
Experiments in mechanically ventilated dogs indicate that racemic ketamine (2 mg/kg) increases cerebral blood volume and ICP even in the presence of normoventilation, a response that is reversible by hyperventilation or the administration of diazepam.	2.214544630119481
Studies in patients have shown that racemic ketamine (2.0 mg/kg) reduces CBF in the presence of cerebral vasodilators like halothane or N2O.	2.2160264541868613
In contrast, studies in unanaesthetised humans showed increases in CBF after racemic ketamine (2-3 mg/kg).	2.218292514214386
This observation is consistent with animal studies and suggests that the cerebrovascular effects of racemic ketamine are related to the pre-existing cerebrovascular tone induced by background anaesthetics.	1.9285833903897691
Dengue-Fever is a mosquito transmitted viral disease.	2.1620723013651126
It is endemic mainly in South-East Asia and Afrika.	2.0013830702258275
The clinical manifestation is divided into different stages.	2.372992339092162

The purpose of this study was (1) to determine the prevalence of hepatitis B (HBV), hepatitis C (HCV) and HIV infections among drug abuse-related fatalities (drug deaths) in Hamburg from 1985 to 1997, (2) to assess the rate of multiple infections and (3) to analyze the liver histomorphology in 100 autopsied drug deaths.	2.284560107605859
Furthermore, we discuss the epidemiological and forensic aspects.	2.452352872295834
In this period 1469 drug deaths were registered with a prevalence for HBV of 35% (1997: 39%), for HCV 51% (1997: 58%), and for HIV 7% (1997: 15%).	2.0715545375041238
Co-infections were common (28%) and 19% of all cases were infected with HBV and HCV.	2.3223931263301645

Only 9% showed a normal liverhistology.	2.5242214272869883
