Type I, insulin-dependent diabetes (IDDM), which becomes manifest before the age of 40, is the result of an absolute deficiency of insulin.	2.3986041707932477
Type II, the non-insulin-dependent diabetes (NIDDM), develops in the elderly and is caused by a relative insulin deficiency.	2.4609324715476544
Patients with type-I diabetes are prone to the development of ketoacidosis, while type II causes hyperglycaemic, hyperosmolar, nonketotic coma.	2.108510878356678
Apart from these acute metabolic alterations, the long-term complications of diabetes are of concern to the anaesthesiologist.	2.2369909171234714
Hypertension, coronary artery disease, renal insufficiency and autonomic neuropathy are common and can result in myocardial ischaemia, cardiovascular instability and gastroparesis, with an increased risk of aspiration.	2.4642004538242417
Limited movement of the atlanto-occipital joint can cause difficult intubation.	2.2335281017777326
To avoid perioperative metabolic catastrophy, blood glucose concentration should be kept between 6.7 and 10 mmol - l-1 (120 - 180 mg - dl-1).	1.9572207777281363
Hypoglycaemia can result in neurological damage, whereas hyperglycaemia causes impaired wound healing and susceptibility to infections and worsens ischaemic damage to the myocardium and brain.	2.1595077665412474
Perioperative diabetes management depends on the severity of the surgical procedure and the type of diabetes.	2.9784228615336947
All type-I diabetics, whatever operation being performed, need insulin.	2.107842755159824
The intravenous route is recommended as it allows better adjustment.	2.382908580908467
After determination of the fasting blood glucose level, insulin is given at a dosage of 0.5 - 1 U - h-1 (at gluc<11.1 mmol - l-1), 1.5 - 2 U - h-1 (at gluc 11.1 - 16.7 mmol - l-1) or 3  U - h-1 (at gluc>16.7 mmol - l-1).	1.9227009070779657
In addition, 5 - 10 g glucose - h-1 is given.	2.5052070359477367
In type-II diabetes the oral antidiabetic drug is withheld.	2.1606983921828586
During minor surgery the blood glucose concentration is monitored frequently, and if necessary insulin (with gluc>13.9 mmol - l-1) or glucose is given.	1.9996193487354645
In most cases of major surgery insulin therapy will be necessary.	2.306485370239227
Administration should follow the guidelines listed for type-I diabetes.	2.213135089850085
Whether the intravenous or the subcutaneous route is used for insulin, repeated glucose determinations are mandatory.	2.0494968108640648
If ketoacidosis develops the volume depletion is treated with normal saline.	2.2304787979084066
For hyperglycaemia and acidosis insulin (3 - 6 U - h-1) with 10 - 20 mmol - h-1 potassium phosphate is given.	2.3222552495442184
Bicarbonate is only indicated when the serum pH is lower than 7.1.	2.381978740041975
It must be borne in mind that perioperative management of diabetes does not end with postanaesthesia care.	1.9443259216029511
At the beginning of the 19 th century, institutional care for the insane was established by the various German states.	2.038311626535393
At first, the separation of curable and incurable patients influenced psychiatric care and the construction of hospitals.	2.041970569858991
The combination of care and cure in one hospital in Illenau was a turning point in institutional care.	1.9828692810673638
Contradictory tendencies characterized the second half of the 19 th century: the integration with general medicine in the cities, on the one hand, the social separation and cure in the seclusion of the countryside, on the other.	2.040379470955322
The characteristic psychiatric construction in different countries was influenced by individual architects.	2.066479476415724
The following building styles were dominant: in England, panoptic architecture; in the United States, linear staggered structures; in France, the "carrés isolés"; and in Germany, the structure of blocks with cross-axes.	1.869969204202497
At the end of the 19 th century, the system of pavilions was internationally accepted; occupational therapy and mental care in the countryside were introduced.	1.9399863858285475
From the First World War until the end of the 1960 s, a standstill in psychiatric buildings was noted in Germany, and institutional care came under increasing criticism.	2.055520711694763
There was a reorientation from the middle of the 1970 s as a result of more effective therapeutic possibilities.	2.240801631645466
A variety of complementary institutions, outpatient and partly inpatient therapies, which were recommended by the "Psychiatrie-Enquête", started to be realized.	2.0410250763459667
Smaller units and different models of integration of psychiatric care, such as building the hospital next to a general hospital or psychiatric wards within a general hospital, became relevant criteria for planning the construction of psychiatric hospitals, as did the integration into the community and the city.	2.0293377893543383
Principles of organization like the construction of a communicative quiet inner room, or grading the rooms from public to private, were structurally integrated.	1.8014042771356402
Specific structural requirements for the construction and design of psychiatric hospitals should be evaluated in more detail by post-occupancy methods.	2.1489958702871355

Biliary tract complications usually occur within the first 3 months and require interventional radiological or surgical therapy.	2.2237118596529664

However, radiological diagnosis of lymphoproliferative disorder has to be confirmed by liver biopsy.	2.493641062713748
Conclusion: Cholangiography and Duplex sonography are routinely used in the postoperative evaluation of patients with OLT.	2.8667498971059495
CT, MRI, and angiography are problem-solving tools in equivocal cases.	2.2379839933905727
Recurrence of colorectal carcinomas occurs in about 50 % of the cases with localized neoplasia.	2.5752545609308037
It is understood that the tumor recurrence is due to residual micrometastases not found during surgery or extraregional (peripheral blood or bone marrow).	1.9735201351807539
We developed a procedure to detect non-visible, abdominal metastases using a radiolabeled anti-tumor cell antibody injected before the operation (radioimmunoguided surgery, RIGS).	1.8902238719110642
However, even with the best technique, it is not possible to remove all micrometastasis if a hematogenic dissemination happens.	2.314154737577505
Based on the knowledge of disturbing humoral immune reaction is mounted against shed tumor associated antigens (TAA), we developed a new method to reduce and correct the B cell response and B cell recruitment due to chronic TAA immun complex presentation on follicular dendritic cells (immune corrective surgery, ICS).	1.7709531961042095
This method is based on a selective lymphadenectomy.	2.8917938022494445
The target lymph nodes were those loaded with TAA-immune complex.	2.1230222039776683
From 20 patients (stage I, II and III) treated with ICS, 17 survived more than 5 years ' showing a statistically significant increase of survival compared to patients treated with standard procedures.	2.1582748329165784
In conclusion, these data show that surgery of colorectal cancer should be selectively extended to specific anatomical regions in order to remove hidden micrometastases, and more importantly, correct postoperative immune processes that could suppress the T cell response against residual tumor cells.	2.014637087791405

The function of local newspapers has not yet been investigated.	2.4089809111579337

Methods: Thirty physicians with different levels of experience in acetabular surgery were divided in three groups of 10 each: group I comprised residents without operative experience in acetabular surgery, group II was physicians with 3-10 years of operative experience, and group III was experts in acetabular surgery.	2.0151913825540912
A total of 10 complete radiographic cases of high quality providing all levels of preoperative diagnostics (plain radiographs, 2-D-CT, CT with multiplanar reformation, 3-D-CT, Fs-CT) of different acetabular fracture types were prepared.	2.0100261013624503
The task for each candidate was to classify the fracture according to Letournel and to identify all additional injuries within the hip joint (e. g. marginal impaction, head fractures, etc.).	1.9810805147325994
The different diagnostic "levels" could be ordered stepwise according to personal need and no time limit was given.	1.873697862418114
The case was finished when the candidate presented his final diagnosis.	2.0740171678292647
The use of the different radiographs, the preliminary diagnosis, the changes in diagnosis, and the final decisions were recorded.	2.6513010609130254
These findings were correlated with the different levels of experience and against a "consensus classification" which was generated by thorough discussion, and the use of intraoperative information and postoperative radiographs not accessible to the candidates.	2.3650001488332406
Results: The "correct" fracture classification based on plain radiographs was: group I, 11 %; group II, 32 %; group III, 61 %.	2.1007497898957
Based on 2-D-CT a "correct" diagnosis was reached by 30 % in group I, by 55 % in group II, and by 76 % in group III.	2.466689521813974
With consideration of the "transient forms" in acetabular fractures based on Letournel and the 3-D-CT used mainly by group I, the rate of "correct" classifications rose to 65 % in group I, 64 % in group II and 83 % in group III.	2.2826863192966527
The modifiers were diagnosed "correctly" in group I by 37 %, in group II by 56 %, and in group III by 73 %.	2.5040983966408685
The use of the 3-D-CT and especially the Fs-CT by group I resulted in an improvement in the rate of correct classifications to 61 %, whereas in group II the Fs-Ct was used only exceptionally.	2.3453970223848732
In particular, the secondary reformations in CT and the 3-D-views dramatically improved the rate of "correct" classifications in the group of surgeons with limited personal experience in acetabular surgery.	2.230037910635939
This allows the less experienced an acceptable level of "correct" diagnoses, so that the treatment options can be weighed correctly.	2.1617791627181258

The reconstruction of the scaphoid or scapholunate ligament in stage II and III is no reasonable option.	2.43583133184106
Motion preserving procedures such as proximal row carpectomy or midcarpal arthrodesis are preferable in this situation.	1.9914100081664394
Thirty-one male patients (average 41 years) were treated for SNAC or SLAC wrist with midcarpal arthrodesis.	2.196342870682514
All patients were reexamined, the mean follow-up was 15 months.	2.567392880496115
Grip strength was measured with the Dexter-System, pain was evaluated by a visual analogue scale (VAS 0-100).	2.196366713083718
Patients' daily activities and general quality of life were estimated with the DASH-questionnaire.	2.252192013513123
Pain was reduced to 50% compared to the preoperative situation.	2.944415304909849
Grip strength improved to 60% of the opposite side.	2.5239945953348544
Active range of motion reached 50% of the contralateral wrist.	2.9521147703575976
Nonunion at the fusion site necessitated additional surgery in four patients resulting in total wrist arthrodesis.	2.1321186745192806
80% of the patients returned to their original occupation.	2.9119005939782787
Midcarpal fusion is a reliable procedure for treating the difficult condition of advanced carpal collapse is proper realignement of the carpus is performed.	1.9403749698444577
The DASH-score reflects the subjective impressions of the patients in daily life and justifies the choice of a salvage procedure preserving wrist mobility.	2.2873765169450384
Total wrist fusion represents the last line of defense.	2.2071632610949883
Stress fractures are one of the most common overuse injuries seen in athletes, accounting for up to 20 % of all injuries presented to sports medicine clinics.	2.2792904136493033
Runners are particularly prone to these injuries, however, it is difficult to predict injury as there is usually a critical interplay between the athlete's biomechanical predisposition, training methods, and other factors such as diet, and muscle strength and flexibility.	2.2505736040236686
This article will discuss the key clinical findings for the majority of stress fractures encountered in a sports medicine practice.	2.1826909048011593
A classification scheme will also be described that will allow the clinician to make appropriate treatment decisions based on the degree of risk for each injury.	2.289106707736956
Today, enzyme therapy with proteolytic enzymes still only plays a minor role in clinical practice, partially due to the belief that intestinal resorption of macromolecules is impossible.	2.0723635205143784
However, there is scientific evidence of intestinal resorption and a subsequent increase in proteolytic serum activity, and placebo-controlled randomised clinical trials have demonstrated positive effects of enzyme therapy.	2.075915121400389
The documented effects include the reduction of oedema and resorption of haematoma, resulting in pain reduction and better mobility.	2.207058361103112
There are indications to use such therapies in the areas of general surgery, traumatology, plastic surgery, and dental surgery.	2.037624301261482
A further effect is higher tissue concentration of antibiotics in combination with proteolytic enzymes.	2.420602510344422
In gynaecological treatments, enzymes are administered in breast surgery and to reduce the side effects of obstetrical injuries.	2.349932524308478
Breast engorgement is a further indication for enzyme therapy.	2.3086126937532203
Further studies concerning enzyme therapy are justified because of the interesting possibilities offered by these substances and a favourable relationship between costs and benefits.	2.059006901865923
High-frequency ventilation and inhaled nitric oxide represent - among others - two treatment options in hypoxemic respiratory failure of neonates.	1.9298705388592972

It is possible to produce a considerable number of these facsimiles from the same real object.	2.495885457975868
With this method we can produce models of human structure for medical teaching, training and research.	2.1117623555108067

Intrinsic positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEPi) occurring during mechanical ventilation depends on expiratory time constants, expiratory volume and expiration time as well as on external flow resistance (tubes, valves, etc.).	1.9014105346506243
It is not routinely determined in mechanically ventilated patients, but it is necessary to optimize respirator settings.	2.562825391431726
The aim of the present study was the validation of an automated PEEPi determination method implemented in the respirator EVITA (Drägerwerke, Lübeck) in mechanically ventilated patients with acute lung failure.	1.9857800008763147
The method was validated in ten sedated, myorelaxed patients with respiratory insufficiency of different etiologies (five with restrictive, and five with obstructive pulmonary disease).	1.920365105233279
PEEPi was determined using the volume constant ventilatory mode at ZEEP or at an external PEEP of 5 as well as 10 cm H2O.	2.2573061303468687
PEEPi was first determined with the automated method implemented in the EVITA (five measurements at each end-expiratory pressure level; PEEPEvita).	1.9555739283525537
These values were compared to the results obtained with end-expiratory occlusion (external, computer-controlled valve in the inspiratory limb of the circuit) at the respective pressure levels (PEEPEEO).	2.194408277352311
The average of five measurements at each PEEP level with each method was defined as PEEPi for the particular ventilatory situation.	1.9954319052164486
Gas flow was measured at the proximal end of the endotracheal tube with a heated pneumotachometer (Fleisch no.	2.1849846618484112
2, Fleisch, Lausanne, Switzerland) and a differential pressure transducer.	2.496150844259073
Tracheal pressure was determined in the same position with a further differential pressure transducer (Dr. Fenyves & Gut, Basel, Switzerland).	2.122817883568584
After A/D conversion, data were sampled with a frequency of 20 Hz and processed on an IBM compatible PC.	1.931171574293299
Software for data collection and processing as well as for control of the occlusion valve was self-programmed.	2.6031194427153217
For the statistical analysis we used the Mann-Whitney U-test or Wilcoxon signed-ranks test; a P value less than 0.05 was considered significant.	1.8480786820094923
At the given respiratory setting and without PEEP patients with obstructive lung disease had a higher PEEPi (median: 6.4 cm H2O; range: 5.0 - 9.6 cm H2O) than those with restrictive pulmonary disease (median: 2.3 cm H2O; range: 0.8 - 3.0 cm H2O) (P<0.05).	1.8325149679176242
Increasing external PEEP to 5 or 10 cm H2O significantly decreased the pressure difference between PEEPi and external PEEP (P<0.05), but was unable to eliminate it completely.	2.1335373772493025
There was no statistically significant difference between PEEPEEO and PEEPEvita (P=0.43; Wilcoxon signed-ranks tests).	1.9841624332106018
Regression analysis showed a highly significant correlation between PEEPEEO and PEEPEvita values (r=0.985, P<0.001; y=1.03x-0.18).	1.9843501412696058
PEEPi occurs during ventilation in patients with obstructive and restrictive lung disease.	2.7610033018101316
The difference between external end-expiratory pressure and PEEPi decreases with increasing external PEEP.	2.0995492376193963
However, PEEPi may increase with increasing external PEEP in some instances.	2.1297097163917993
The reason for this may be that the PEEPi determined at the proximal end of the endotracheal tube represents only a mean value of different PEEPi values of various lung regions.	2.0052070082713525
Increasing external PEEP only partially alters this mean value due to an effect on PEEPi values lower than external PEEP.	2.096894519275674
The PEEPi values measured by the EVITA respirator compared with classical end-expiratory occlusion with an external valve were nearly identical.	2.053776346424339
Unfortunately, PEEPi measurement of the EVITA can only	2.751523714730654

Total effective antiemetic response was defined as the absence of nausea and vomiting for 24 h postoperatively.	2.6871182717115847

Hydromorphone is a µ receptor agonist opioid.	2.306514351396413
According to WHO recommendations, hydromorphone is to be classified in step III of pain therapy.	2.219561225027326
An oral formulation with a prolonged duration of action of 12 hours has been evaluated only recently.	2.2191002395555754
The controlled release capsule is especially suited for the regular twice a day administration in cases of severe and persistent pain.	2.2911965962086267
The oral formulation of hydromorphone increases the number of opioid analgesics available for pain therapy in step III.	2.3383754403980053
Hydromorphone is recommended when morphine fails to produce sufficient pain relief (despite increase of doses) or causes intolerable side effects (despite treatment of symptoms).	1.9112158690552647
In principle, no differences in efficacy of morphine and hydromorphone are to be expected.	2.384183573809437
However, clinical experience shows that changing one opioid analgesic to another one can improve the treatment of patients so that hydromorphone may replace another opioid analgesic to which a patient fails to respond well or develops side effects.	2.0064479615366744
The dose of hydromorphone equivalent to 2 times 30 mg controlled release morphine is about 2 times 4 mg.	1.921133240524691
The values for the absorption, bioavailability and maximum plasma concentration after the administration of controlled release hydromorphone every 12 hours -of three times the dose- are equivalent to those of an immediate release tablet given every 4 hours.	1.977213127827547
In several open label and controlled studies, hydromorphone proved to be of good efficacy in the treatment of acute and persistent pain, especially in patients with severe cancer pain.	2.881385951020951
With regard to the incidence of side effects, no significant differences between morphine and hydromorphone could be established.	2.947541764554018

Multiple metastases were found in her lymph nodes, liver, lung and skeleton.	2.6675805633952216
The patient died eleven weeks after the first symptoms of bullous pemphigoid appeared.	2.4933143907922424
Acute compartment syndrome of the thigh has been infrequently reported in the literature.	2.185865298213419
Closed femoral fractures and blunt soft tissue trauma are the main causes of this injury.	2.468231049272644
The multiple injured patient in this case report developed a compartment syndrome of the thigh after intramedullary nailing of a comminuted fracture of the femur.	2.34585542995065
Fasciotomy was performed two days after surgery because of extense swelling of the thigh in the ventilated and sedated patient.	2.209530248387605
Sciatic and femoral nerve palsy was recognized after extubation of the patient nine days after the injury.	2.493179800480942
During the following weeks the paresis of the femoral nerve recovered but neither motor nor sensory function of the sciatic nerve could be demonstrated.	2.206530538284408
Therefore an operative revision of the sciatic nerve was performed eighteen weeks after trauma.	2.152185498115817
No direct nerve injury could be detected but there were adhesions around the nerve as a sign of compression neuropathy caused by the compartment syndrome.	2.2360924395891697
The tibial component of the sciatic nerve showed a complete recovery within the next months but there was a persisting peroneal nerve palsy.	2.2980403865665733
Conclusion: Early clinical symptoms of a compartment syndrome like pain, paresthesia and paresis can not be ascertained in a ventilated and sedated patient.	2.0220363017330643
Tense swelling of the muscles is often the only detectable sign.	2.5164932306677534
Frequent measurements of compartment pressure should be done in these patients.	2.49430243352039

In a fatality after oral intake of a large amount of an insecticide spray consisting of propoxur, tetramethrine and the solvents isopropanol and benzyl alcohol, a coagulation nectrotic fixation of the oesophagus and stomach were the main morphological findings.	1.8427803878454228
The concentrations determined by HPLC and GC/MS in femoral blood, liver, kidney, vitreous humor and liquor were in the comatose lethal range for propoxur (< 0.3-18 µg/g), whereas tetrametrin (up to 0.1 µg/g) was almost completely decomposed.	1.8829349831371582
The propoxur decomposition product o-isopropoxyphenol (2.8-56 µg/g), benzyl alcohol (18-58 µg/g) and its oxydation product benzoic acid (85-140 µg/g), isopropanol (0.45-1.1 mg/g) and acetone (0.01-0.03 mg/g) were also found.	1.899884696414068
On the other hand, the concentrations in heart blood and lung tissue were up to 30 times higher.	1.9711500495768395
As a reason for these immense concentration differences an agonale aspiration of the highly concentrated liquid stomach content after vomiting immediately before death is discussed.	1.7738331269852656
The extent of the metabolization of propoxur to o-isopropoxyphenol and of benzyl alcohol to benzoic acid, which is assumed to proceed mainly postmortem, was quite different in the materials investigated and was almost complete in the liver.	1.9843674169093293

Simpson in Scotland was the first to describe the administration of ether for analgesia in painful deliveries.	2.3746630300067415
Only a few days later E.C.J.	2.4666574249253737
von Siebold (*1801 in Würzburg - \dagger1861 in Göttingen) performed the first systematic study on ether in obstetrics.	1.79596574945485
Following a preceding evaluation of the action of ether on non-pregnant woman and on pregnant women not in active labour, he administered ether for analgesia during the second stage of labour in eight parturients.	1.9549858743089665
The first administration was on February 25th 1847.	2.1471631856785676
While he was satisfied with the good analgesia without sequelae of the new-born, he was discouraged by the termination of uterine contractions observed in all his patients.	1.959588172044975
He concluded that ether was not a useful substance for analgesia during vaginal delivery, since it disturbed the natural course of labour.	2.002039752731485
On the other hand, von Siebold was very pleased with the administration of ether for operative obstetric procedures such as forceps deliveries or placental retention.	1.8674671043981566
Background: Mode switching aims to maintain a ventricular rhythm that matches metabolic needs during both sinus rhythm and atrial tachyarrhythmias.	1.963136227953548
This allows patients with atrial arrhythmias to benefit from AV synchronous pacing modes.Aim and method: Beat-to-beat mode switching in Diamond and Clarity pacemakers is designed to maintain a relatively stable ventricular rhythm, ensuring consistent ventricular filling patterns.	1.8206600116544038
Atrial tachyarrhythmia detection is based on a continuous analysis of the atrial rhythm.	3.1667824664328026
A too rapid increase of the atrial rate with a beat-to-beat acceleration > 15 bpm is considered to be an atrial tachyarrhythmia.	2.445700925310753
Mode switching occurs on detection of the first premature atrial event: atrial tracking is stopped and the ventricular rate is determined by the rate indicated by the dual sensor (QT interval and activity).	2.101588268631254
Atrial pacing restores AV synchrony immediately after cessation of the atrial tachyarrhythmia, effectively avoiding retrograde conduction.	2.0335551364392357
Dedicated diagnostic functions allow one to monitor the incidence of atrial tachyarrhythmias and to study atrial and ventricular events just prior to its onset.	2.3817441208213213
Both the mode switching and rate responsive function are fully automatic, rendering follow-up procedures easy and less time-consuming.	2.0985398002557347
Conclusion: Reliable detection of all atrial events is essential to guarantee appropriate mode switching.	2.189378102426938
Therefore, the pacemaker stores the distribution of the amplitude of all atrial events, both during sinus rhythm and atrial tachyarrhythmias, which facilitates the appropriate programming of the atrial sensitivity.	2.0494253008865764
Introduction: Mediastinal diseases are mostly diagnosed by CT and MRI.	2.56940094236218

Blood glucose alterations prior to cerebral ischaemia are associated with poor neurologic outcome, possibly due to extensive lactic acidosis or energy failure.	2.0020464485679006
Cerebral effects of hyper- or hypoglycaemia during cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) are less well known.	2.07025960007078
In addition, little information is available concerning cardiac effects of blood glucose alterations.	2.1208700332873742
The aim of this study was to evaluate the effects of pre-cardiac-arrest hypo- or hyperglycaemia compared to normoglycaemia upon haemodynamics, cerebral blood flow (CBF) and metabolism (CMRO2), and regional cardiac blood flow during CPR subsequent to 3 min of cardiac and respiratory arrest and after restoration of spontaneous circulation.	1.9007463060209964
After approval by the State Animal Investigation Committee, 29 mechanically ventilated, anaesthetised pigs were instrumented for haemodynamic monitoring and blood flow determination by the radiolabeled microsphere technique.	1.7486131437024415
After 3 min of untreated ventricular fibrillation and respiratory arrest, CPR (chest compressor/ventilator (Thumper) and epinephrine infusion) was commenced and continued for 8 min.	1.8366283312403746
Thereafter, defibrillation was attempted, and if successful, the animals were observed for another 240 min.	2.0934603155032865
Cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP), CBF, CMRO2, coronary perfusion pressure (CorPP), and regional cardiac blood flow were determined at control, after 3 min of CPR, and at 10, 30, and 240 min post-CPR.	2.0897047745456727
In group I, 4/9 animals (44%) could be successfully resuscitated; in group II 4/10 (40%); and in group III 0/10 (0%).	2.376511590999296
Prior to cardiac arrest, mean arterial pressure, CPP, and CorPP in group III were significantly lower compared to groups I and II.	2.199124005614588
In group I, CPP during CPR was 26 +/- 6 mmHg; CBF 31 +/- 9 ml/min/100 g CMRO2 3.8 +/- 1.2 ml/min/100 g; CorPP 18 +/- 5 mmHg; and left ventricular (LV) flow 35 +/- 15 ml/min/100 g. In group II: CPP=21 +/- 5; CBF 21 +/- 7; CMRO2 1.8 +/- 0.8; CorPP 16 +/- 6; and LV flow 22 +/- 9; and in group III: CPP 15 +/- 3; CBF 11 +/- 8; CMRO2 1.5 +/- 1.1; CorPP 4 +/- 2; and LV flow 19 +/- 10.	2.078017645585341
During the 240-min post-resuscitation period, there were no differences in CBF, CMRO2, or LV flow between groups I and II.	2.0467478976037836
Hypoglycaemia prior to cardiac arrest appears to be predictive for a poor cardiac outcome, whereas hyperglycaemia does not impair resuscitability compared to normoglycaemia.	2.1453332479483156
In addition, hyperglycaemia did not affect LV flow, CBF, or CMRO2.	1.9922720679538803
However, it has to be kept in mind that haemodynamics and organ blood flow do not permit conclusions with respect to functional neurologic recovery or histopathologic damage to the brain, which is very likely to be associated with hyperglycaemia.	2.4777678275720874
Normal urinary organic acids in patients with non-specific clinical features and normal results of brain imaging render the diagnosis highly unlikely, and no further investigations are required.	2.500802272959763
In other patients, the diagnostic strategy depends on the individual clinical, neuroradiological and biochemical findings.	2.6008855834174396
GCDH enzyme analysis should be reserved for patients in whom GA1 is very likely.	2.31325227997229

Malignant lymphomas, originating from peripheral T or NK cells, are rare tumours in Europe and account for less than 10% of all malignant lymphomas.	2.1384403988051437
In this review, the salient features of the more frequently occurring entities derived from T or NK cells will be presented.	2.003632564904196
Nasal NK/T cell lymphoma is mainly found in the nose and paranasal sinuses and often, but not always, display an angiocentric growth pattern leading to coagulation necrosis.	2.08855726773886
The tumor cells consistently express CD56, CD2 and the EBER molecules encoded by the Epstein-Barr virus.	1.8400496243544184
Enteropathy-type intestinal T-cell lymphomas often arise in patients with celiac disease and have a dismal prognosis.	2.5661863017089788
The tumour cells express T cell antigens, CD103 and cytotoxic molecules, but are negative for CD4.	1.984930007285289
Approximately 20% of the cases display CD56 mostly in combination with CD8.	3.0606065318671973
Recently, an early purely intraepithelial form of this tumour was identified.	2.287797951615527
Histologically these cases resemble celiac disease, however the intraepithelial lymphocytes often exhibit an abnormal immunophenotype with absent CD8 and T-cell-receptor protein expression, and, they are clonal by molecular analysis.	1.9854875509908625
Clinically, the patients suffer from refractory sprue or ulcerative jejunitis.	2.2018769002725005
The prognosis is bad with the patients often dying from malnutrition or an invasive tumour-forming T-cell lymphoma.	2.092433750051366
Angioimmunoblastic T-cell lymphoma is defined by characteristic morphological findings (atypical lymphoid cells in part with pale cytoplasm, arborizing high endothelial venules and large FDC-meshworks) as well as clinical features (systemic symptoms, signs of a dysregulated immune response).	2.0006484645976
Peripheral T-cell lymphomas, that do not fit into a distinct entity, are classified in the REAL and the new WHO classifications as peripheral T-cell lymphomas unspecified.	2.170055090708307
These display a broad morphological spectrum (including the T-cell lymphomas of different cell sizes, Lennert's lymphoma and T-zone lymphoma of the Kiel-classification) and in general are clinically aggressive.	2.069020625087777
Causes and courses of the diseases are subjected to a change of an increasing life expectancy on the one hand and technically highly developed medicine on the other hand.	2.1714654274846446
Since a growing number of elderly people is denying intensive medical interventions which serve the purpose of keeping them alive despite severe diseases, the problem of euthanasia imposes direct questions.	1.987959494748413
A central role is played by the active-passive difference and its moralistic legitimacy.	1.9806997387070597
The difficulties of this difference are discussed below on the applicable level of ethical discussions.	2.001059874642566
At the same time, knowledge of the danger is being made aware that in a maximal therapeutical orientated medical care system the desire for euthanasia may become identical with the reverse side of this care system.	1.9840973743872405
Isolated severe head trauma (SHT) or SHT in combination with multiple injuries are important factors for the prognosis of morbidity and mortality in patients suffering from the consequences of accidents.	2.574555505548754
The prognosis mainly depends on the presence of primary mechanic brain injury and the development of secondary brain damage.	2.676701763341183
Causes for the development of secondary brain damage are the intracranial space demand after traumatic injury and edema formation which may result in iscemia, as well as inflammatory processes.	2.3775980516703443
Both isolated SHT and polytrauma with or without brain damage may result in a systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) due to the synthesis of cytokines and other inflammatory mediators which may cause a single or multiple organ failure (MOF).	2.2359282808416263
Often the organism is able to survive isolated traumatic injuries and functional disturbances, but in combination or cumulation they may be lethal.	2.2096876101955747
The hypermetabolism after SHT is often regarded as an interaction between the central nervous system and the whole organism by the activation of the neuroendocrine axis.	2.47325554048589
In contrast to the consequences of SHT for the whole organism, multiple injuries after polytrauma may affect brain functions, such as the shock dependent disturbance of the brain perfusion accompanied by brain hypoxia which may lead to an aggravated prognosis.	2.11478970159441
Moreover, coagulation, metabolism and fracture healing are influenced by the onset of SIRS as well.	2.388085348644887
Our knowledge about the bidirectional inflammatory interaction between brain and whole organism is still limited.	2.2157666527690574
In this context, the effects of secondary surgical interventions which may additionally stress a traumatized body have to be considered and are the subject for actual clinical discussions and experimental studies.	2.1138943179063037

Abstract The term acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) reflects an acute worsening of the stable state with an increase in dyspnea, cough, and count or purulence of sputum.	1.938533563645316
The management of an acute exacerbation is guided mainly clinical severity which has implications on the decision of outpatient management, hospital management or intensive care treatment.	2.0064811465668244
Cardiopulmonary comorbidity and the number of previous exacerbations are prognostic factors.	2.6939669746766897
The first-line therapy of each exacerbation is the intensification of drug-treatment with 2-agonists and anticholinergics.	2.197166225081221
Systemic steroids as a short-term course are advocated if hospital-treatment is necessary.	2.4413919345599226
Infections of the respiratory tract are a frequent cause of acute exacerbations.	2.7836841798735925
However, a colonization with potential pathogenic microorganisms is found in many patients in the stable state.	2.3427019557701434
Antibiotic treatment is justified if cardiopulmonary comorbidity and frequent previous exacerbations are present.	2.208394216188192
The severity of airflow obstruction and the frequency of previous exacerbations are linked to the spectrum of the underlying microorganisms.	2.451405138542517
This should be borne in mind for the choice of the antimicrobiotic treatment.	2.208491492829499
As a consequence the number of intubations and the attributable morbidity and mortality are reduced.	2.526382588240006

Method: From 1982 to 1997 Hartmann's operations were performed in 103 patients for colonic perforations.	2.218122723785131
In 63 % of cases inflammatory diseases caused colonic complications.	2.2031854875778554
The average Mannheimer Peritonitis Index (MPI) was 19.	2.0923727704749973

In 69 patients (80 %) intestinal restoration could be performed after an average interval of 122 days (complication rate: 6 %, no mortality).	2.1224206259134752
On follow-up, patients were asked to give information on their general state, changes of housing, abdominal complaints, and quality of life.	2.3338169813081855
Results: Data on 93 % of patients could be obtained.	2.3904024381319524

Electrocardiographic and clinical characteristics are currently used as diagnostic criteria for the long QT-syndrome.	2.41500915243598
In borderline electrocardiographic findings associated with unclear syncope, it is often difficult to ensure or exclude long QT-syndrome.	2.261631006596736
Schwartz and coworkers therefore created a point system as a guide in clinical decision making.	1.9864738208870776
In recent years genetic diagnostics have entered the arena of long-QT assessment.	2.0983513591215637

Performing linkage analysis, coupling of autosomal-dominant congenital long QT-syndrome (Romano-Ward Syndrome) to chromosomes 11 (LQT1/11p15.5), 3 (LQT3/3p21), 7 (LQT2/7q35), and 4 (LQT4/4q25-27) was demonstrated.	1.9204427616919992
More recently, the disease genes in long QT-syndrome 1, 2, and 3 could be identified.	2.4016181973367074
Analysis of the base-pair sequence allowed detection of several different mutations in different families illustrating genetic heterogeneity.	1.9121695134467438

Application of interventional techniques has permitted the development of a novel, endovascular implantable bypass system.	2.257855862415898
The device is placed within the lumen of the superficial femoral artery.	2.135121904932434
The present study investigated the technical properties of the new system in cadavers, with subsequent evaluation of its application in humans.	2.203744488979724
Methods: The endopass consists of a thin-wall polycarbourethane tube with a total length of 53 cm.	2.1767216873884943
The distal end is connected with a self-expanding stent prothesis 4 cm in length.	2.1643326312342612
Endovascular implantation is performed through a groin incision.	2.3312024755912097
Following antegrade ringstripper-TEA, the endopass is introduced into the femoral artery after placement of a guide wire.	2.311060386608823
The proximal anastomosis is performed surgically.	2.402477203004982
Results: The technical requirements and feasibility of the system were tested on 12 cadaver extremities.	2.234188758820658
Implantation of the device proved technically successful in seven of eight extremities with significant occlusion of the superficial femoral artery.	2.162494259400021
The most important problems included the complete ringstripper-TEA, the placement of the guide wire following the TEA, and the expansion of the endopass.	2.1706895709681184

In order to evaluate patients' exposure to radiation in computed tomography, dose quantities such as the computed tomography dose index (CTDI), multiple scan average dose (MSAD) and dose free in air on the axis of rotation are used.	1.8554833054068005
The CTDI and the MSAD, derivable from the CTDI, are a good measure for the absorbed doses in the examined volume, but they do not take the biological sensitivity of the organs into account and do not describe the radiogenic risk that is actually relevant for patients and doctors.	1.945489275873179
The dose on the axis of rotation is not an accurate measure of the effective dose and the radiogenic risk.	2.170981168878874

Prognosis of patients surviving acute myocardial infarction has substantially improved over the last two decades.	2.5416130178185847
However, stratification of patients at risk for death due to arrhythmic events remains a clinical challenge.	2.2845198440762977
Due to the important role of the autonomic nervous system in the genesis of sudden death, autonomic markers such as heart rate variability and baroreflex sensitivity have recently gained attention as risk stratification parameters.	2.1058666333015554
The present study reports the results of noninvasive risk stratification in 411 consecutive postinfarction patients treated due to contemporary therapeutical guidelines with a high proportion of patients discharged with a patent infarct related artery.	2.0535746567023287
The diagnostic arsenal of risk parameters comprised heart rate variability, baroreflex sensitivity, and more traditional markers such as non-sustained ventricular tachycardia, left ventricular ejection fraction, and ventricular late potentials.	2.11152525345323
Patiens were followed for a mean of 33  +/- 21 months.	2.55663671661028
Stepwise logistic regression analysis revealed that left ventricular function, both autonomic markers, and the patency of the infarct related artery were independent predictors of the prospectively defined primary study endpoint, i.e., all-cause mortality plus ventricular tachyarrhythmic events.	2.031644057330563
With respect to the secondary endpoint (ventricular tachyarrhythmic events), left ventricular function, heart rate variability, and infarct vessel patency were independent predictors.	2.1622049089239495
Ventricular late potentials and nonsustained ventricular tachycardia had no predictive value with respect to ventricular tachyarrhythmic events.	2.3079620478903338
These findings from a large prospective long-term study demonstrate the value of markers of cardiac autonomic tone in identifying infarct survivors at risk for malignant ventricular tachyarrhythmias and sudden death.	2.157796131897712
K+ Channels and Cardiotoxicity of Drugs: Implications for Drug Toxicity Assessment - The time required for repolarization of the ventricles can be measured as the QT interval of the ECG and is determined primarily by activation of the delayed rectifier K+ current (IK), which consists of a rapid component (IKr) and a slow component (IKs).	1.9533008710154498
Drugs that block cardiac IKr prolong the cardiac action potential (AP).	1.965652768981992
Prolonged repolarization is detected as a longer QT interval on the ECG.	2.1261594240187898
During prolonged APs, increased inward currents induce early afterdepolarizations, which increase the risk of Torsades de pointes (TdP) cardiac arrhythmias.	1.914088412577768
TdP arrhythmia is characterized by an apparent twisting of the electrical axis around the isoelectric line.	2.187162337482181
It has a rate of 150 to 250 beats/min and it can occasionally degenerate into ventricular fibrillation that may be fatal.	2.15004642850799
The incidence of drug-induced TdP arrhythmias is highest among class IA and class III antiarrhythmic agents.	2.0118358098732534
However, under certain clinical conditions, also several non-cardiovascular medicinal products induce QT interval prolongations in the ECG or TdP arrhythmias.	1.8239872658381893
Since all drugs known to cause TdP block IKr, an early evaluation of possible effects on APs of cardiac myocytes expressing IKr channels during the developmental phases of novel drugs seems to be recommended.	1.9726854269944996
If in-vitro electrophysiological studies show the new active substance to induce AP prolongation and/or K+ channel blockade in appropriate models and at relevant concentrations,  either further development of the new active substance may not be justified or the risk factors predisposing to TdP arrhythmias should be taken into account in further clinical studies.	2.139422919111964
Carcinoma of the penis is a malignant epithelial tumor of ominous prognosis if not adequately treated.	2.1464341496455623
To a large extent the probability of positive lymph nodes is determined by the grade of the primary lesion.	2.6098421542468193
In turn the number of positive nodes greatly influences the survival.	2.610132559155948
In the past the complications of radical ilioinguinal lymphadenectomy have decreased their timely indication.	1.9606006703642345
If delayed lymphadenectomy is performed, the survival rate is reduced by approximately 50 % as compared to the results of immediate lymphadenectomy.	2.7462959166603382
The modified inguinal lymphadenectomy described by Catalona leads to less complications.	2.064750125762921
If performed without delay it should lead to improved survival in patients with higher stage and high grade penile cancer.	2.435734548931908
Recently suggested employment of adjuvant and neoadjuvant chemotherpy may further enhance the survival.	2.0051397566291174

The examination is structured in 5 phases: the opening scene, exploration of specific examples for relationships, exploration of experience of self and others, of therapy motivation, and finally clarifying the preconditions for treatment and the ability for insight.	1.9153923041754262
The syndrome diagnosis according to ICD 10 is completed in a final phase.	2.1136293703517604
This psychodynamic-diagnostic assessment interview is recommended, apart from the use for OPD diagnosis, for use a clinical instrument.	2.1921288165566124
Cryptococcal meningitis is one of the most frequent forms of meningoencephalitis in AIDS patients.	2.457275868167381
Before the introduction of triazol antibiotics like difluconazole, the frequency of this meningitis among AIDS patients was 5-10%, yet declined during the last years.	2.327420110912152
Clinically, nonspecific signs of a meningeal inflammation predominate while focal neurological signs are rare.	2.1706767576008414
Rapid institution of high-dose antimycotic therapy is the keystone to improve prognosis and decrease mortality.	2.469987059149111
Antimycotics of choice are amphotericin B, fluconazole, and flucytosin.	2.2868529441088903
Diagnosis is established by detection of cryptococcal antigen in cerebrospinal fluid, microscopic demonstration of cryptococci using India-ink, and cryptococcal cultures.	1.7626180845618749
Recent developments aim to improve antimycotic therapies.	2.3544547701196956
During the last years, life-long secondary prevention with difluconazole was established.	2.139577896860094
Cryptococci which are resistent against fluconazole and amphotericin B are a special challenge, yet fortunately are rare.	1.9183895329010154
Longterm outcome of patients is determined by the progression of the underlying immunsuppression.	2.9976438929805513
Therefore, combination of secondary prophylaxis with modern antiviral substances is important.	2.1477512859915664
Clinical decision analysis in patients with suspected cryptococcal meningitis is presented using methods from evidence-based medicine.	2.39529622837191

Coagulation parameters were monitored intraoperatively using a mobile laboratory.	2.325058906550635
In contrast to the published results, no effect on transfusion requirements could be demonstrated.	2.19726136273649
However, aprotinin showed a positive effect on some coagulation parameters in the reperfusion phase.	2.266510980570398
The mechanism appeared to be inhibition of the contact activation of the intrinsic system with less thrombin generation in the study group.	2.395803827230115

The pattern ERG (PERG) is used as an indicator of retinal ganglion cell function.	2.213301192753245
Up to now, reports on the reproducibility of the PERG have been contradictory.	2.1274328401530256
We investigated the reproducibility under the conditions of the forthcoming ISCEV guidelines for the PERG.	2.2268135481261995
We simultaneously recorded the PERG and VEP in 42 eyes of 21 subjects to phase-reversing checkerboard stimuli with DTL electrodes.	1.7537158118508156
Both transient (2 rps) and steady-state (16 rps) stimulation was employed.	2.002599476841779
The check sizes were 0.4 °, 0.8 ° and 16 °, the mean luminance 45 cd/m2, the contrast 98%, and the field size 32 °x27 °.	2.202135121710309
Measurements were repeated at the same time of day after 1 week.	2.5532591658096813
In addition, we compared two different electrode positions in 16 eyes: (1) across the cornea along the lower lid; and deep in the conjunctival sac.	2.053770194576038
With position (1) the amplitudes were found to be higher by 20% than (2).	2.8720174199940076
We calculated the coefficient of variation (CV) of amplitude as a measure of reproducibility.	1.990730180609471
For the latency of the PERG, the intersession CV was found to be 1.5%.	2.362764336910182
Altogether, the amplitude reproducibility of the PERG is somewhat higher than that of the VEP.	2.297279627830481

Less than 5% of the patients show a subclavian artery aneurysm, but 76% have obstructions of digital arteries.	2.485563959973863
Every patient, must undergo a neurological examination including the measuring of the proximal ulnar and median nerve conduction times.	2.1144114380994017
Anatomical lesions of the subclavian artery, reduction of the proximal nerve conduction times and high-degree venous compression as well as disabling pain during the night with abuse of analgesics are absolute indications for the decompression of the neurovascular bundle.	2.5396505123894406
This is achieved by the transaxillary exarticulation of the first rib together with a cervical rib and fibromuscular bands if present.	2.3150610368553175
The results of the primary operation are favourable: completely painfree 85%, markedly improved 12%, unchanged or worse 3%.	2.1541087652447746
The results of operations for persisting and recurrent TOS are disappointing: completely painfree 48%, markedly improved 31%, but 21% unchanged or worse.	1.805632808350415
Regional perfusion of the lung is not distributed homogeneously within the organ.	2.4885554973745982
This phenomenon has been explained by the classical concept of West et al.	2.092975128911443
based on the isolated canine lung.	3.2348337436113135
The concept stresses the importance of different gravitational forces along the vertical axis of the lung resulting in three zones in which no pulmonary perfusion (zone 1), waterfall-like perfusion (zone 2), and continuous blood flow (zone 3) prevail.	2.3130341892093584
A new concept of distribution of regional pulmonary perfusion is presented which centers on vascular factors which are better suited to account for observed blood flow heterogeneities.	1.9030000849159823
The pulmonary vasculature is composed of repetitions of one structural unit: the vessel bifurcation.	1.9449506590136934
Apart from its size, each single bifurcation is similar to all others.	2.162345042941552
The pulmonary vessel tree can, therefore, be considered to be self-similar.	2.5393761775791055
Self-similarity has been identified as a design principle of living nature.	2.32523156192054
Self-similar objects can produce heterogeneity which is also self-similar when viewed at different scales of magnification.	1.9299079299644024
For measurement of the structure of such objects and their function, i.e., in this case the heterogeneity of pulmonary perfusion, fractal geometry is best suited.	2.2858023131807084
Distribution of blood flow within the lung can be described by means of fractal analysis, and all phenomena of perfusion distribution can easily be explained when applying this concept.	2.306663469564152
Furthermore, since the basis of fractal analysis is pulmonary vascular anatomy, it lends itself for the study of blood flow distribution.	2.4616434646292182
A major advantage is the independence of fractal parameters from resolution of perfusion measurements.	2.0168041161451002
Thus, fractal analysis can be used to compare results that have been obtained using different resolutions and different species.	2.343193107557656
Fractal methods have previously been used in medicine for other purposes.	2.4237286763628094
Nonlinear analyses of heart beat variability can predict the onset of malign cardiac dysrhythmias hours before actual appearance in the ECG.	2.101898569511388
Very similar methods applied to electrical brain activity have been shown to allow prediction of epileptical seizures approximately 15 min prior to appearance of clinical symptoms.	2.0079911474371026
In part II we report about the clinical application of the EPTT in 67 patients with a wide spectrum of repairs and reconstructions of the extensor mechanism.	2.601148439498392
48 patients had fresh injuries, 18 of them with severe concomitant knee lesions and 19 patients had neglected rsp.	2.1269945331746993
There were 4 deep infections, two of them related to the MPT fixator.	2.3773275413609354
In the patients with uneventful healing the fixator remained in place for 7.3 weeks in average.	2.125988166973776
The clinical, isokinetic and radiological results were reviewed in 17 patients with an average follow-up time of 37.3 months.	2.535413572126175
There were 5 patients with partial patellectomy and tendon reattachment because of lower patella pole comminution and 12 patients with tendon reattachment ruptured at the inferior patella pole or suture repair in midsubstance rupture.	1.8712694675849149
The clinical results according to the IKDC score were rated in 3 patients as normal, in 10 patients as nearly normal and in 4 patients as abnormal.	2.2167602170933667
This rating was highly dependend on the subjective judgement by the patients who considered their operated knees not as normal as the contralateral knees.	2.1226582555524383
From our clinical experiences and results we can derive that the EPTT enables the surgical management of extensor mechanism disruptions with a minimum of internal fixation material and provides a safe protection of the repairs and reconstructions during the healing period.	1.9591747837325042
The EPTT allows immediate unrestricted functional rehabilitation and early walking without crutches.	2.025702784165538
Thus the EPTT represents an effective alternative to the patello-tibial cerclage with a wire or synthetic ligaments.	1.9688381583559975
Ondansetron is more effective than a placebo in treating postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV), but it has not been proved to be superior to established antiemetics for prophylaxis or therapy.	2.4618971883265153
We compared ondansetron vs droperidol for the treatment of PONV.	2.7024146607241963
Our prospective, randomized double-blind study was performed between 15 October 1992 and July 1993; it included 271 gynaecological ASA I - III inpatients who had been operated on under general anaesthesia with intubation.	2.1058196573762786
Patients were excluded if: there was no informed consent; it was an ambulatory or emergency operation; the patient was pregnant or breast feeding; allergies were being treated with antihistamines; drug addiction was present or convulsions or Parkinson's disease; any pre- or intraoperative antiemetic medication had been administered.	1.903376117160267
All patients wishing an antiemetic and/or suffering from at least one emetic episode during the first 24 h postoperatively received either 8 mg ondansetron or 1.25 mg droperidol from identical 4 ml ampoules intravenously.	2.0127724579486754
The verbal nausea score (1=none, 2=mild, 3=moderate, 4=severe) was recorded every 30 min for 4 h, then before and 2 h after each antiemetic dose.	1.921164350437134
All emetic episodes and the interval between administration and effect were also noted.	2.1635327103415056
Patients were interviewed 36 - 48 h postoperatively on subjective effects, side-effects and individual acceptance.	2.1991373469988953
After oral premedication with diazepam, anaesthesia was induced with thiopental, in a few cases with etomidate or propofol.	2.21404687526544
Relaxation was achieved with pancuronium or atracurium and, when indicated, with succinylcholine.	2.183235802778027
Muscular relaxation was antagonized with neostigmin and glycopyrrolate.	2.171450306229574
Gastric content was aspirated once after intubation.	2.303738247259951
Anaesthesia was maintained with nitrous oxide/oxygen, enflurane, halothane or isoflurane and fentanyl up to 0.3 mg. Statistical evaluation was performed by the unpaired Student's t-test and the Mann-Whitney U test.	1.9524327237337091
Categoric variables were examined by the 2 test.	2.7532630910110734
Significance was defined as P<0.05.	2.8636894249928324
Of 271 patients, 100 (37%) experienced PONV.	2.3209038268075552
The groups were statistically comparable with respect to demographic data, type and duration of operation, emesis record, perioperative uterotonic medication.	2.332061586988474
Nausea scores and emetic episodes were identical before antiemetic medication.	2.1569364891506617
The reduction of these parameters after medication was similar.	2.2922071623148415
Complete response over 6 h was 60% in the ondansetron and 68% in the droperidol group.	2.3069505367113243
In both groups the first medication failed in 4 cases during the initial 2 h. Twenty of the ondansetron and 16 of the droperidol patients needed a second dose; among these 2 and 4, respectively, a third ampoule.	2.0500445331473416
No rescue medication was necessary over 24 h and a mean of 1.4 ampoules was administered in both groups.	2.1848115759116755
Onset and quality of emetic action were identical in both groups.	2.318387483401528
It was not possible to evaluate 25 interviews due to linguistic or amnestic problems.	2.1277340123169326
Multiple side-effects were noted frequently.	2.9260896176239446
Injection pain was reported significantly more often in the droperidol, pruritus in the ondansetron group.	2.3439716836952447
Ninety-three percent of the ondansetron and 85% of the droperidol patients opted for the same drug for future PONV treatment.	2.0757263309043865
Ondansetron (8 mg) and droperidol (1.25 mg) proved to be equally effective when used as a postoperative antiemetic.	2.3219771693145814
Both drugs showed similar side-effects.	2.565212836739787
Due to differences in methods it was difficult to compare our results to those obtained in other studies.	2.1508365645462857
Paradoxical embolism is well-known in theory but rarely encountered in clinical practice.	2.41632117342214
The typical pathophysiological background is the coincidence of venous thrombosis, elevated right atrial pressure, and a consecutive right-to-left shunting via a patent foramen ovale or an atrial septal defect.	2.23634068871575
This review summarizes the results of internal cardioversion of atrial fibrillation in comparison to external cardioversion.	2.881370793655032
Internal cardioversion was achieved by positioning defibrillation electrodes in the right atrium and coronary sinus (alternatively in the left pulmonary artery).	2.4002308600597186
In previous studies also a combined internal/external cardioversion was used by locating a defibrillation electrode in the right atrium together with a cutaneous patch electrode.	2.0003018446654215
Although in comparative studies the success rate of 91-93% with internal cardioversion is higher compared to success rates of 67-79% with external cardioversion, the conventional method of external cardioversion remains the method of first choice.	2.006080373744195
The success rate of internal cardioversion after failed external cardioversion ranges from 73 to over 90%.	2.0618430951111884
Possible indications for primary internal cardioversion are: induced atrial fibrillation during electrophysiological studies, atrial fibrillation after cardiothoracic surgery and cardioversion of atrial fibrillation in patients with permanent pacemaker implants.	2.165458004080984
Objective: The objective of the study is to evaluate the importance of home care for patients with advanced tumor diseases and for their families.	3.1919356921955018
VDD single-lead systems use floating ring electrodes for atrial sensing.	2.0868499454981873
To ensure an optimal atrial sensing function, knowledge of the interactions between electrode design, pacemaker, amplifier and implantation technique is required.	1.9810377285349643
In this overview, technical determinants of atrial sensing concerning atrial ring configuration (surface area, ring spacing, full/half ring), design of the lead (insulation material, conductor coil configuration), and amplifier design (differential amplifier, sensing impedance, bandpass filter) shall be explained and related to determinants at implant (AV distance, site of implantation, atrial position, intraoperative measurement technique).	1.7520053362793635
(1) Ring configuration: Bipolar atrial full ring systems have proved to be efficient with narrow (5-10mm) or wide (15-30mm) ring spacing, as well as bipolar half ring systems with DAB configuration and narrow ring spacing.	2.109313891622067
Especially in a position close to the atrial wall, a wide ring spacing detects a less clear-cut signal than a short ring spacing; on the other hand, with a wide ring spacing, sensing is less compromised if the rings move to a worse position further away from the wall.	2.0086879888691636
A narrow ring spacing detects a sharper signal if positioned close to the atrial wall, but a considerable reduction of sensed P wave amplitude may result if it moves away from the wall or to an oblique angle relative to the atrial depolarization front.	1.8870856076502651
(2) Design of the lead: Polyurethane as insulation material provides a higher stiffness than silicone insulation.	2.049813575015128
A coaxial conductor configuration increases stiffness and consequently the possibility to manipulate the atrial part of the lead.	2.2967433773552233
Thus, if a position close to the atrial wall is desired, the combination of a coaxial conductor coil, polyurethane insulation, and a narrow ring spacing seems most promising.	2.1593825561112605
(3) Amplifier design: For atrial sensing in VDD systems, bipolar sensing, differential amplifier, high sensing impedance (>=2k), and a wide bandpass filter (e.g., 10-100Hz) should be realized.	2.1300362935101806
Especially the inclusion of a relatively low frequency range (10-40Hz) is important, because compared to a fixed atrial electrode, a higher quantity of the atrial signal sensed by a floating electrode is in the low-frequency range.	2.1858336119052337
A position of the ring electrodes in the mid-to-high right atrium parallel to the lateral wall should be the goal.	2.5700901465490964
Correct interpretation of the sensed P wave amplitude and prediction of sufficient sensing after connection with the pacemaker is only possible with exact knowledge of the measurement technique of the intraoperative pacing system analyzer and the connected permanent pacemaker device (bandpass filter, signal peak-to baseline or peak-to-peak).	1.9492175418940696
Attention should be paid to the fixation of the electrode at the site of insertion to avoid postoperative dislocation of the ring electrodes.	2.3941554402546035
Knowledge of different electrode/pacemaker specific parameters and special aspects at implantation is a prerequisite for optimal function of VDD single-lead systems.	1.9079923157267453
Preoperatively, considerations should concern the choice of the electrode (AV distance, ring spacing) and implantation strategy (position close to or rather apart from the atrial wall).	2.0181684411828633
An atrial position may only be accepted if sufficient sensing can be documented with a measuring method similar to that of the implanted pacemaker.	2.13408313160889
Objectives: To investigate the agreement (and its potential dependency on extravascular lung water) between transpulmonary (TPID) and standard pulmonary artery (PAID) thermodilution cardiac output  measurements.	1.7814038899541826

In nearly 50% the complaints persist over many years of their life-span to adolescence or adulthood.	1.8590841973620087
Although the empirical findings have increased in the last decade, our knowledge about the etiology, pathogenesis, and pathophysiology is still very limited.	2.3159820142599314
Current approaches suggest that we understand recurrent pain syndromes as a complex and multidimensional disturbance (biopsychosocial paradigm).	1.868441667880082
In this respect there is strong evidence for the major importance of psychosocial causes (daily hassles, specific life events), psychopathological factors (anxiety, depression, somatization disorder), and social environmental influences (mother's psychopathology, social modelling, reinforcement) in the pathogenesis of functional abdominal pain.	2.0096463553389885
The noticeable correlation with other pain syndromes and functional disturbances indicates that recurrent pain may possibly be a manifestation of a basic somatization disorder.	2.081489530413192
The unfavourable long-term prognosis supports the need for early and specific interventions.	2.575907082363679
Psychological treatment requires a medical examination to exclude organic origins.	2.278028551861404

The psychological interventions applied in clinical practice include prophylaxis, reduction of pain symptoms and environmental modification.	2.361319672154017
Although preliminary data on the use of these behavioural medicine programs have shown some promise, further investigations are needed to examine the applicability and effectiveness of specific interventions in the treatment of abdominal pain symptoms.	2.5460029493659766

Moreover, we examined the correlation of intra-pair differences with the age of the monozygotic twins.	2.5172107498159675
A greater difference in older twin pairs than in younger pairs could show the effect of an exogene influence.	2.1199678464659035
In addition to the few phoniatric studies in twins in the literature, we used current methods for acoustic analysis.	2.3159689640882095
We examined seven parameters of vocal performance and three acoustic features in 31 monozygotic twin pairs (median age 36 years, range 18-75 years) and compared them with 30 control group pairs, which consisted of non-related persons of the same age and sex, newly combined from the group of monozygotic twins ("statistical twins").	1.985078330274553
We found significant differences in seven of ten parameters (vocal range, highest and lowest vocal fundamental frequency, fundamental speaking frequency, maximum voice intensity, number of partials, vibrato of intensity; U-test by Mann-Whitney).	1.8177191234863483
No correlation of the differences of the identical twins with age was found in the examined parameters.	2.5949474868512694
The voices of identical twins are significantly more similar than those of non-related persons regarding the above mentioned features.	2.1997339612563733
Thus, the suitability of the voices of monozygotic twins for professions with a high demand on voice is comparable.	2.08556529920654
Results of the group comparison correlate largely with the literature.	2.3625733543922416

One of these vein groups forms a tight plexus around the testicular artery.	1.991560437018319
Computer-aided 3-D reconstructions based on the paraffin serial sections of the human spermatic cord allowed us to demonstrate the relation between the blood vessels and the other tissue structures of the spermatic cord.	2.480664032514035
The results obtained allowed us to subdivide the human spermatic cord into three compartments.	2.0894990342036666
The dorsomedial compartment contains the vas deferens and its blood vessels.	2.1085761514960093
The middle compartment contains the testicular artery and the vein group which forms a tight plexus around this artery.	2.1062397906379053
The ventrolateral compartment contains a vein group which shows no topographic relation to the testicular artery.	2.209949010567408
This vein group is embedded in a large, macroscopically visible volume of fatty tissue.	2.081207883761135
To be sure of sparing the testicular artery during antegrade sclerotherapy this vein group should be prepared.	2.011008286682019
It has known for a long time that Sydenham's chorea and tics, as seen in Gilles de la Tourette's syndrome (GTS), are phenomenologically very similar.	1.903029494642998
Tics may occur as symptoms of acute Sydenham's chorea or persist over years as residual symptoms.	2.0446179232799566
Investigations of children suffering from GTS, including obsessive-compusilve symptoms, have provided signs of a poststreptococcal autoimmune process but also shown that treatment based on immunological interventions has been effective.	1.8876863740422671
We treated a 14-year-old boy showing all diagnostic criteria of GTS, familial susceptibility, and an increase in the antibody titer of streptococcal antigens with 7S immunoglobulins i.v.	2.120208038260672
Response to this therapy was good regarding motor tics, vocal tics, and behavioral symptoms such as disturbed impulse control which still persisted after 9 months.	1.8738324315354133
These findings and the successful therapy underline reports of the literature and point to a pathogenetic mechanism of an immunologically triggered disturbance of the striatal dopaminergic system, at least in a subgroup of GTS.	2.159700903921974

The high rate of coronary artery disease (CAD) mortality needs preventive intervention.	2.401702201361404
Several studies have documented the effectiveness of LDL-cholesterol lowering in CAD primary prevention.	2.26615949042568
The West of Scotland Prevention Study resulted in risk reduction by about one third through LDL-cholesterol lowering.	1.9556898219390564
The data indicate that specifically patients at high risk benefit from lipid reduction.	2.224059534508027
High risk patients have besides high LDL-cholesterol one or more additional risk factors such as family history of premature coronary artery disease, hypertension, smoking, low HDL-cholesterol or diabetes.	2.10430819572483
This strategy allows to reduce the number of patients needed to treat in order to prevent one CAD event (56 in isolated hypercholesterolemia) to 14-24 in high risk persons, approaching the number (n=13) known for effective lipid lowering in secondary prevention of coronary heart disease.	2.0289639604028378
One hundred and three cases of Spitz nevi were reviewed.	2.415290183635743
36% of these patients were adults.	3.2652579777952413
The lesions in children occurred primarily on the face and secondarily on the trunk followed by the extremities.	2.3718333906343694
In adults, they affect the legs in women, and the trunk in men as does malignant melanoma.	2.39720172314138
Clinically they were diagnosed more frequently as Spitz nevi in children and adolescents than in adults.	2.2486472674298166
Histologically, there are various expressions of Spitz nevi, but they are usually compound melanocytic nevi with little pigmentation and typically large spindle- and/or epithelioid melanocytes.	2.206225038019697
There are only small histopathological differences between Spitz nevi in childhood and adulthood: one important feature rarely seen in Spitz nevi of adults is multiple mitotic figures at the dermo-epidermal junction but rarely at the base of the melanocytic nevus.	1.7366104195248073
Nevus Reed is considered to possibly be a distinctly pigmented variant of Spitz nevus.	2.2689752674879977

Radiological and orthopaedic outcome in severe and moderate haemophilia A and B patients undergoing long-term prophylactic treatment were prospectively investigated focusing on the age of onset of prophylaxis and the number of joint bleedings prior to treatment.	2.372494477913397
Three patient groups were evaluated according to the age at onset of prophylaxis.	2.7840823852345147
In group I (n = 8) prophylactic treatment was initiated in the first 2 years of life.	2.559543129297494
Patients of group II (n = 6) received prophylaxis at the age of 3-6 years.	2.6472697867605763
Late-onset or secondary prophylactic treatment was started at the age of 6 years and above in 7 patients (group III).	2.387334452357361
All patients received virus-inactivated F VIII or F IX concentrates at dosages of 30-40 IU, in some cases up to 50 IU/kg body weight i. v. three times per week for those with haemophilia A and twice per week for those with haemophilia B. Elbow, knee and ankle joints were investigated at 3-4 yearly intervals according to the radiological and orthopaedic scores recommended by the World Federation of Haemophilia (WFH).	1.8835685959432023
The total number of joint bleedings before and after start of prophylaxis were recorded in all patients.	2.400539026350553
In group I 7 out of 8 patients had unaffected joints with constant radiological and orthopaedic scores of zero or 1, after a median of 11.25 years of prophylactic treatment.	1.9269474964150983
One patient in this group demonstrated mild radiological alterations (score 4).	2.277595208006325
Patients of group II showed neither radiological nor orthopaedic alterations at study entry.	1.9546869894873178
Worsening joint scores could be detected despite ongoing prophylaxis after the 3-year interval (median orthopaedic score 4, median radiological score 8).	2.160788062134204
Treatment group III already showed considerable joint damage at study entry with a median radiological score of 11 (0-33) and a median orthopaedic score of 4 (0-11).	2.218873971639247
Despite prophylactic treatment both, orthopaedic (median 8, range 2-12) and radiological scores (median 19.5, range 2-47) deteriorated after 3 years.	1.9405254496397994
Prior to onset of prophylaxis no or only one joint bleeding occurred in treatment group I.	2.2062431505744637
In group II, a median of 6 joint bleeds (range 1-8) were reported before prophylaxis was started.	2.290500035655734
Patients of group III usually experienced a median of more than 10 joint haemorrhages (range 6-10 or more).	2.33877726173506
Under prophylactic treatment the number of joint bleedings decreased significantly in groups II and III.	2.613369593560047
However, radiological and orthopaedic scores increased as a sign of progressing osteoarthropathic alterations in patients reporting more than 6 joint haemorrhages before onset of prophylaxis whereas no joint alterations could be assessed in patients with no or only one joint bleeding episode prior to prophylaxis.	2.107640083939065
Even a small number of joint bleedings seems to cause irreversible osteoarthropathic alterations leading to haemophilic arthropathy.	2.1323107795424394
Once apparent, further progression of joint damage could not be arrested despite of prophylactic treatment (group II and III).	2.3508761302911827
In order to prevent haemophilic arthropathy, effective prophylaxis should be started before or at least after the first joint bleeding in severe haemophilia A and B.	2.167541380219884
The hemodynamic treatment of septic shock consists of fluid repletion, maintenance of an adequate cardiac output, and restoration of mean arterial pressure.	2.0717083933761047
Norepinephrine is a potent vasopressor that can be considered when the patient is adequately fluid resuscitated, when cardiac output is greater than 3.5 l/min/m2 (or Sv O2>=65%) and when blood pressure remains low.	2.259862717927228
The objective is to achieve and maintain a mean arterial pressure of 60-70 mmHg, or more in some patients (older or hypertensive patients).	2.0499121405677947
Renal effects of norepinephrine were evaluated in several studies; urine output, creatinine clearance, and osmolar clearance are significantly increased.	2.0505962891902914
Norepinephrine is perfectly suited in situations of high renal output and low renal resistance, as is the case in septic shock patients.	2.0181446820495292
The effect on oxygen transport is unpredictable.	2.2680315211008892
The effects on lactate concentrations were poorly evaluated, but several studies suggest that the drug does not worsen and can even improve tissue oxygenation of septic shock patients.	1.9895632569529187
Provided that cardiac output is maintained, treatment with norepinephrine is without negative effects on splanchnic tissue oxygenation.	2.126597089612008
In conclusion, the clinical experience with norepinephrine strongly suggests that this drug can successfully increase blood pressure without deteriorating cardiac output and organ function.	1.9881572536967154
Whether using norepinephrine in septic shock patients effects mortality as compared to dopamine or epinephrine still requires a prospective study.	2.207550907620585

Even after the strengthening by the law of 1997, the German criminal law regarding corruption is no obstacle for cooperation between medical research and industry.	2.007884297839929
The injustice of corruption is an irregular exchange between performing one's duty and benefits.	1.9331974412117703
According to this, an enterprise may give funds to a scientist for research purposes if no counter performance exceeding the research is associated with this.	2.115297897921747
However, it makes a difference if the scientist has to show his appreciation by influencing economic decisions of the clinic in favor of the enterprise.	1.8977121584448589
In case of such an injustice, it is, under the new law, no longer important if the benefit is destined for the scientist himself or for another person or organization.	1.9837191619870331
Thus, it is in the interest of both research and industry to avoid the suspicion of corruption in the first place.	2.6337173460110077

The out-of-hospital treatment consists of oxygen (6 Ll/min) via a face mask, furosemide 80 mg i.v., opioids 10 mg s.c., and either sublingual nitroglycerine (n=23; initial dose: 0.8 mg; repetitive application of 0.8 mg every 10 min until a cumulative dose of 3.2 mg) or intravenous enalaprilat (initial dose: 2.5 mg; repetitive application of 2.5 mg every 30 min until a cumulative dose of 10 mg).	1.7444342840373421
The aim of the antihypertensive treatment was a reduction of systolic blood pressure below 160 mm Hg and diastolic blood pressure below 90 mm Hg until admission to the emergency department.	2.098591994083711
In the emergency room, an arterial and venous blood sample was taken to determine the respiratory (pO2, pCO2) and metabolic status (pH value; base-excess; serum lactate) of the patient.	2.178088812627161
Successful antihypertensive treatment was observed in 13/23 (57%) patients of the enalaprilat group and 15/23 (65%) patients of the nitroglycerine group (p=0.54).	2.2414102557948863
Systolic and diastolic blood pressure on admission were similiar in both treatment groups (systolic RR: enalaprilat: 179 [31] mm Hg; nitroglycerine: 184 [38] mm Hg; p=0.59; diastolic RR: enalaprilat: 96 [14] mm Hg; nitroglycerine: 101 [14] mm Hg; p=0.12).	1.7945764784004483

Intravenous enalaprilat did not exhibit any advantage compared to nitroglycerine in terms of blood pressure reduction or respiratory and metabolic parameters on admission to the emergency room.	2.2435827374230812
We conclude that enalaprilat is no substitute for nitroglycerine in the out-of-hospital treatment of hypertensive patients with pulmonary edema.	1.9372592642333313

The ethics of interrupting life-sustaining treatment in critically ill patients have been worked out by a Task Force on Ethics of the Society of Critical Care Medicine (1990).	1.959800079224383
A consensus was found that the patient may judge to forego therapy; ethically it is then appropriate to withhold or withdraw therapy.	2.063941770335177
According to the consensus, withdrawing an already initiated treatment should not necessarily be regarded as more problematic than a decision not to initiate treatment.	1.9652723644687693
In my mind, however, there is a great difference between withdrawing or withholding, e.g., ventilation.	2.6027154988384127

The material were tested as loops with a length of 30 mm including the knot similar to intraoperative conditions.	1.9508715302089459
The ultimate tension load and elongation of the conditioned and unconditioned loops were investigated under cyclic load of 50 N and 100 N using a tension load machine.	1.822498618913966
The ultimate tension load increased significantly only for Mersilene from 416 N to 462 N. However, the highest ultimate tension load showed Polylene with 479 N. The elongation decreased significantly for the conditioned loops to a maximum of 1.4 mm.	2.1813284012160965
Concerning the amplitude during the period of oscillating load there was found a significant reduction as well.	2.3594610865929537
Based on our results Polylene showed the best mechanical properties.	2.2369023875021963

There were no accidental permanent RLN palsies.	2.1521509795711915

Dysphagia is related to the impairment of food passage from the mouth to the stomach.	2.4241648800711295
Globus pharyngis implies the frequent and often painful sensation of a lump in the throat that usually does not interfere with swallowing and may even be relieved by food intake.	1.724160258852114
The diagnosis is based upon a careful history, clinical examination, endoscopy, dynamic imaging (videofluoroscopy, cinematography, videosonography) and electrophysiologic procedures (including pharyngoesophageal manometry, electromyography and pH determinations).	1.8671483234012634
Structural lesions of the cervical spine such as diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis are rare causes of dysphagia.	2.364721216826069

OD was localized in 46 cases on the femoral condyle and in 26 cases on the talus.	2.332461149590006
Radiological methods were performed simultaneously and shortly before definite arthroscopical therapy.	2.135704854562076
Using conventional radiography, OD of the condyles was staged according to the classification of Rodegerdts and Gleissner and OD of the talus suggested by Berndt and Harty.	2.1355595810791903
MRI staging was performed by morphology of the interface of the OD.	2.561385257717751
Arthroscopical staging based on the classification of Guhl.	3.1954764256090735
There was an excellent correlation between the stages in MRI and arthroscopy, showing correct prediction of stable and unstable fragments in 92%.	2.0175769214616537
In contrast, fragment stability could not be efficiently assessed by conventional radiology because fragments could be stably fixed in cases of bony separation.	2.153568000305827
